play.title: The Third Part of Henry the Sixth

scene.stagedir: Enter Plantagenet, Edward, Richard, Norfolke, Mount-ague, Warwicke, and Souldiers

speech.speaker: Warwicke.
speech.line: I Wonder how the King escap’d our hands?

speech.speaker: Pl.
speech.line: While we pursu’d the Horsmen of y North,
He ſlyly ſtole away, and left his men:
Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland,
Whose Warlike eares could neuer brooke retreat,
Chear’d vp the drouping Army, and himselfe.
Lord Clifford and Lord Stafford all a-brest
Charg’d our maine Battailes Front: and breaking in,
Were by the Swords of common Souldiers ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Lord Staffords Father, Duke of Buckingham,
Is either ſlaine or wounded dangerous.
I cleft his Beauer with a down-right blow:
That this is true (Father) behold his blood.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: And Brother, here's the Earle of Wiltshires blood,
Whom I encountred as the Battels ioyn’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Speake thou for me, and tell them what I did.

speech.speaker: Plan.
speech.line: Richard hath best deseru’d of all my ſonnes:
But is your Grace dead, my Lord of Somerset?

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Such hope haue all the line of Iohn of Gaunt.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thus do I hope to ſhake King Henries head.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And ſo doe I, victorious Prince of Yorke.
Before I ſee thee ſeated in that Throne,
Which now the House of Lancaster vsurpes,
I vow by Heauen, these eyes ſhall neuer close.
This is the Pallace of the fearefull King,
And this the Regall Seat: poſſeſſe it Yorke,
For this is thine, and not King Henries Heires.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Aſſist me then, ſweet Warwick, and I will,
For hither we haue broken in by force.

speech.speaker: Norf.
speech.line: Wee'le all aſſist you: he that flyes, ſhall dye.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Thankes gentle Norfolke, ſtay by me my Lords,
And Souldiers ſtay and lodge by me this Night.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And when the King comes, offer him no violence,
Vnleſſe he ſeeke to thrust you out perforce.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: The Queene this day here holds her Parliament,
But little thinkes we ſhall be of her counsaile,
By words or blowes here let vs winne our right.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Arm’d as we are, let's ſtay within this House.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: The bloody Parliament ſhall this be call’d,
Vnleſſe Plantagenet, Duke of Yorke, be King,
And bashfull Henry depos’d, whose Cowardize
Hath made vs by-words to our enemies.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Then leaue me not, my Lords be resolute,
I meane to take poſſeſſion of my Right.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Neither the King, nor he that loues him best,
The prowdest hee that holds vp Lancaster,
Dares ſtirre a Wing, if Warwick ſhake his Bells.
Ile plant Plantagenet, root him vp who dares:
Resolue thee Richard, clayme the English Crowne.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter King Henry, Clifford, Northumberland, Westmerland, Exeter, and the rest

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: My Lords, looke where the ſturdie Rebell ſits,
Euen in the Chayre of State: belike he meanes,
Backt by the power of Warwicke, that false Peere,
To aspire vnto the Crowne, and reigne as King.
Earle of Northumberland, he ſlew thy Father,
And thine, Lord Clifford, & you both haue vow’d reuenge
On him, his ſonnes, his fauorites, and his friends.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: If I be not, Heauens be reueng’d on me.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: The hope thereof, makes Clifford mourne in
Steele.

speech.speaker: Westm.
speech.line: What, ſhall we ſuffer this? lets pluck him down,
My heart for anger burnes, I cannot brooke it.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Be patient, gentle Earle of Westmerland.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Patience is for Poultroones, ſuch as he:
He durst not ſit there, had your Father liu’d.
My gracious Lord, here in the Parliament
Let vs aſſayle the Family of Yorke.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Well hast thou ſpoken, Cousin be it ſo.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Ah, know you not the Citie fauours them,
And they haue troupes of Souldiers at their beck?

speech.speaker: Westm.
speech.line: But when the Duke is ſlaine, they'le quickly flye.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Farre be the thought of this from Henries heart,
To make a Shambles of the Parliament House.
Cousin of Exeter, frownes, words, and threats,
Shall be the Warre that Henry meanes to vse.
Thou factious Duke of Yorke descend my Throne,
And kneele for grace and mercie at my feet,
I am thy Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I am thine.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: For ſhame come downe, he made thee Duke of
Yorke.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: It was my Inheritance, as the Earledome was.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: Thy Father was a Traytor to the Crowne.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Exeter thou art a Traytor to the Crowne,
In following this vsurping Henry.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Whom ſhould hee follow, but his naturall
King?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: True Clifford, that’s Richard Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: And ſhall I ſtand, and thou ſit in my Throne?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: It must and ſhall be ſo, content thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Be Duke of Lancaster, let him be King.

speech.speaker: Westm.
speech.line: He is both King, and Duke of Lancaster,
And that the Lord of Westmerland ſhall maintaine.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And Warwick ſhall disproue it. You forget,
That we are those which chas’d you from the field,
And ſlew your Fathers, and with Colours ſpread
Marcht through the Citie to the Pallace Gates.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Yes Warwicke, I remember it to my griefe,
And by his Soule, thou and thy House ſhall rue it.

speech.speaker: Westm.
speech.line: Plantagenet, of thee and these thy Sonnes,
Thy Kinsmen, and thy Friends, Ile haue more liues
Then drops of bloud were in my Fathers Veines.

speech.speaker: Cliff.
speech.line: Vrge it no more, lest that in ſtead of words,
I ſend thee, Warwicke, ſuch a Meſſenger,
As ſhall reuenge his death, before I ſtirre.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Poore Clifford, how I ſcorne his worthleſſe
Threats.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Will you we ſhew our Title to the Crowne?
If not, our Swords ſhall pleade it in the field.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: What Title hast thou Traytor to the Crowne?
My Father was as thou art, Duke of Yorke,
Thy Grandfather Roger Mortimer, Earle of March.
I am the Sonne of Henry the Fift,
Who made the Dolphin and the French to ſtoupe,
And ſeiz’d vpon their Townes and Prouinces.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Talke not of France, ſith thou hast lost it all.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: The Lord Protector lost it, and not I:
When I was crown’d, I was but nine moneths old.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: You are old enough now,
And yet me thinkes you loose:
Father teare the Crowne from the Vsurpers Head.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: Sweet Father doe ſo, ſet it on your Head.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Good Brother,
As thou lou'st and honorest Armes,
Let's fight it out, and not ſtand cauilling thus.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Sound Drummes and Trumpets, and the
King will flye.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Sonnes peace.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Peace thou, and giue King Henry leaue to ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Plantagenet ſhal ſpeake first: Heare him Lords,
And be you ſilent and attentiue too,
For he that interrupts him, ſhall not liue.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Think'st thou, that I will leaue my Kingly Throne,
Wherein my Grandsire and my Father ſat?
No: first ſhall Warre vnpeople this my Realme;
I, and their Colours often borne in France,
And now in England, to our hearts great ſorrow,
Shall be my Winding-sheet. Why faint you Lords?
My Title's good, and better farre then his.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Proue it Henry, and thou ſhalt be King.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Henry the Fourth by Conquest got the Crowne.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: 'Twas by Rebellion against his King.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: I know not what to ſay, my Titles weake:
Tell me, may not a King adopt an Heire?

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: What then?

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: And if he may, then am I lawfull King:
For Richard, in the view of many Lords,
Resign’d the Crowne to Henry the Fourth,
Whose Heire my Father was, and I am his.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: He rose against him, being his Soueraigne,
And made him to resigne his Crowne perforce.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Suppose, my Lords, he did it vnconstrayn’d,
Thinke you 'twere preiudiciall to his Crowne?

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: No: for he could not ſo resigne his Crowne,
But that the next Heire ſhould ſucceed and reigne.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Art thou against vs, Duke of Exeter?

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Why whisper you, my Lords, and anſwer not?

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: My Conscience tells me he is lawfull King.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: All will reuolt from me, and turne to him.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Plantagenet, for all the Clayme thou lay'st,
Thinke not, that Henry ſhall be ſo depos’d.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Depos’d he ſhall be, in despight of all.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Thou art deceiu’d:
‘Tis not thy Southerne power
Of Eſſex, Norfolke, Suffolke, nor of Kent,
Which makes thee thus presumptuous and prowd,
Can ſet the Duke vp in despight of me.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: King Henry, be thy Title right or wrong,
Lord Clifford vowes to fight in thy defence:
May that ground gape, and ſwallow me aliue,
Where I ſhall kneele to him that ſlew my Father.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Oh Clifford, how thy words reuiue my heart.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Henry of Lancaster, resigne thy Crowne:
What mutter you, or what conspire you Lords?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Doe right vnto this Princely Duke of Yorke, Or I will fill the House with armed men, And ouer the Chayre of State, where now he ſits, Write vp his Title with vsurping blood.

scene.stagedir: He ſtampes with his foot, and the Souldiers ſhew themselues

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: My Lord of Warwick, heare but one word,
Let me for this my life time reigne as King.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Confirme the Crowne to me and to mine Heires,
And thou ſhalt reigne in quiet while thou liu'st.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: I am content: Richard Plantagenet
Enioy the Kingdome after my decease.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: What wrong is this vnto the Prince, your
Sonne?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: What good is this to England, and himselfe?

speech.speaker: Westm.
speech.line: Base, fearefull, and despayring Henry.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: How hast thou iniur’d both thy ſelfe and vs?

speech.speaker: Westm.
speech.line: I cannot ſtay to heare these Articles.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Come Cousin, let vs tell the Queene these
Newes.

speech.speaker: Westm.
speech.line: Farwell faint-hearted and degenerate King,
In whose cold blood no ſparke of Honor bides.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Be thou a prey vnto the House of Yorke,
And dye in Bands, for this vnmanly deed.

speech.speaker: Cliff.
speech.line: In dreadfull Warre may'st thou be ouercome,
Or liue in peace abandon’d and despis’d.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Turne this way Henry, and regard them not.

speech.speaker: Exeter.
speech.line: They ſeeke reuenge, and therefore will not yeeld?

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Ah Exeter.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Why ſhould you ſigh, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Not for my ſelfe Lord Warwick, but my Sonne,
Whom I vnnaturally ſhall dis-inherite.
But be it as it may: I here entayle
The Crowne to thee and to thine Heires for euer,
Conditionally, that heere thou take an Oath,
To cease this Ciuill Warre: and whil'st I liue,
To honor me as thy King, and Soueraigne:
And neyther by Treason nor Hostilitie,
To ſeeke to put me downe, and reigne thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: This Oath I willingly take, and will performe.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Long liue King Henry: Plantagenet embrace him.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: And long liue thou, and these thy forward
Sonnes.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Now Yorke and Lancaster are reconcil’d.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: Accurst be he that ſeekes to make them fœs.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Farewell my gracious Lord, Ile to my Castle.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And Ile keepe London with my Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Norf.
speech.line: And I to Norfolke with my followers.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: And I vnto the Sea, from whence I came.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: And I with griefe and ſorrow to the Court.

speech.speaker: Exeter.
speech.line: Heere comes the Queene,
Whose Lookes bewray her anger:
Ile ſteale away.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Exeter ſo will I.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Nay, goe not from me, I will follow thee.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Be patient gentle Queene, and I will ſtay.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Who can be patient in ſuch extreames?
Ah wretched man, would I had dy’de a Maid?
And neuer ſeene thee, neuer borne thee Sonne,
Seeing thou hast prou’d ſo vnnaturall a Father.
Hath he deseru’d to loose his Birth-right thus?
Hadst thou but lou’d him halfe ſo well as I,
Or felt that paine which I did for him once,
Or nourisht him, as I did with my blood;
Thou would'st haue left thy dearest heart-blood there,
Rather then haue made that ſauage Duke thine Heire,
And dis-inherited thine onely Sonne.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Father, you cannot dis-inherite me:
If you be King, why ſhould not I ſucceede?

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Pardon me Margaret, pardon me ſweet Sonne,
The Earle of Warwick and the Duke enforc't me.

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: Enforc't thee? Art thou King, and wilt be forc't?
I ſhame to heare thee ſpeake: ah timorous Wretch,
Thou hast vndone thy ſelfe, thy Sonne, and me,
And giu'n vnto the House of Yorke ſuch head,
As thou ſhalt reigne but by their ſufferance.
To entayle him and his Heires vnto the Crowne,
What is it, but to make thy Sepulcher,
And creepe into it farre before thy time?
Warwick is Chancelor, and the Lord of Callice,
Sterne Falconbridge commands the Narrow Seas,
The Duke is made Protector of the Realme,
And yet ſhalt thou be ſafe? Such ſafetie findes
The trembling Lambe, inuironned with Wolues.
Had I beene there, which am a ſilly Woman,
The Souldiers ſhould haue toſſ’d me on their Pikes,
Before I would haue granted to that Act.
But thou preferr'st thy Life, before thine Honor.
And ſeeing thou do'st, I here diuorce my ſelfe,
Both from thy Table Henry, and thy Bed,
Vntill that Act of Parliament be repeal’d,
Whereby my Sonne is dis-inherited.
The Northerne Lords, that haue forsworne thy Colours,
Will follow mine, if once they ſee them ſpread:
And ſpread they ſhall be, to thy foule disgrace,
And vtter ruine of the House of Yorke.
Thus doe I leaue thee: Come Sonne, let's away,
Our Army is ready; come, wee'le after them.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Stay gentle Margaret, and heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Thou hast ſpoke too much already: get thee gone.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Gentle Sonne Edward, thou wilt ſtay me?

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: I, to be murther’d by his Enemies.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: When I returne with victorie to the field,
Ile ſee your Grace: till then, Ile follow her.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Come Sonne away, we may not linger thus.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Poore Queene,
How loue to me, and to her Sonne,
Hath made her breake out into termes of Rage.
Reueng’d may ſhe be on that hatefull Duke,
Whose haughtie ſpirit, winged with desire,
Will cost my Crowne, and like an emptie Eagle,
Tyre on the flesh of me, and of my Sonne.
The loſſe of those three Lords torments my heart:
Ile write vnto them, and entreat them faire;
Come Cousin, you ſhall be the Meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Exet
speech.line: And I, I hope, ſhall reconcile them all.
Exit.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter Richard, Edward, and Mountague

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Brother, though I bee youngest, giue mee leaue.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: No, I can better play the Orator.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: But I haue reasons ſtrong and forceable.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Why how now Sonnes, and Brother, at a ſtrife?
What is your Quarrell? how began it first?

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: No Quarrell, but a ſlight Contention.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: About what?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: About that which concernes your Grace and vs,
The Crowne of England, Father, which is yours.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Mine Boy? not till King Henry be dead.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Your Right depends not on his life, or death.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: Now you are Heire, therefore enioy it now:
By giuing the House of Lancaster leaue to breathe,
It will out-runne you, Father, in the end.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I tooke an Oath, that hee ſhould quietly reigne.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: But for a Kingdome any Oath may be broken:
I would breake a thousand Oathes, to reigne one yeere.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: No: God forbid your Grace ſhould be for-sworne.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I ſhall be, if I clayme by open Warre.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Ile proue the contrary, if you'le heare mee ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Thou canst not, Sonne: it is impoſſible.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: An Oath is of no moment, being not tooke
Before a true and lawfull Magistrate,
That hath authoritie ouer him that ſweares.
Henry had none, but did vsurpe the place.
Then ſeeing 'twas he that made you to depose,
Your Oath, my Lord, is vaine and friuolous.
Therefore to Armes: and Father doe but thinke,
How ſweet a thing it is to weare a Crowne,
Within whose Circuit is Elizium,
And all that Pœts faine of Bliſſe and Ioy.
Why doe we linger thus? I cannot rest,
Vntill the White Rose that I weare, be dy’de
Euen in the luke-warme blood of Henries heart.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Richard ynough: I will be King, or dye. Brother, thou ſhalt to London presently, And whet on Warwick to this Enterprise. Thou Richard ſhalt to the Duke of Norfolke, And tell him priuily of our intent. You Edward ſhall vnto my Lord Cobham, With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise. In them I trust: for they are Souldiors, Wittie, courteous, liberall, full of ſpirit. While you are thus imploy’d, what resteth more? But that I ſeeke occasion how to rise, And yet the King not priuie to my Drift, Nor any of the House of Lancaster. Enter Gabriel. But ſtay, what Newes? Why comm'st thou in ſuch poste?

speech.speaker: Gabriel.
speech.line: The Queene,
With all the Northerne Earles and Lords,
Intend here to besiege you in your Castle.
She is hard by, with twentie thousand men:
And therefore fortifie your Hold, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I, with my Sword.
What? think'st thou, that we feare them?
Edward and Richard, you ſhall ſtay with me,
My Brother Mountague ſhall poste to London.
Let Noble Warwicke, Cobham, and the rest,
Whom we haue left Protectors of the King,
With powrefull Pollicie ſtrengthen themselues,
And trust not ſimple Henry, nor his Oathes.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Brother, I goe: Ile winne them, feare it not.
And thus mo’t humbly I doe take my leaue.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine Vnckles,
You are come to Sandall in a happie houre.
The Armie of the Queene meane to besiege vs.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Shee ſhall not neede, wee'le meete her in the field.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: What, with fiue thousand men?

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: I, with fiue hundred, Father, for a neede.
A Woman's generall: what ſhould we feare?

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: I heare their Drummes:
Let's ſet our men in order,
And iſſue forth, and bid them Battaile ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Fiue men to twentie: though the oddes be great,
I doubt not, Vnckle, of our Victorie.
Many a Battaile haue I wonne in France,
When as the Enemie hath beene tenne to one:
Why ſhould I not now haue the like ſucceſſe?

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: Ah, whither ſhall I flye, to ſcape their hands?
Ah Tutor, looke where bloody Clifford comes.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Chaplaine away, thy Priesthood ſaues thy life.
As for the Brat of this accursed Duke,
Whose Father ſlew my Father, he ſhall dye.

speech.speaker: Tutor.
speech.line: And I, my Lord, will beare him company.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Souldiers, away with him.

speech.speaker: Tutor.
speech.line: Ah Clifford, murther not this innocent Child,
Least thou be hated both of God and Man.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: How now? is he dead alreadie?
Or is it feare, that makes him close his eyes?
Ile open them.

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: So looks the pent-vp Lyon o’re the Wretch,
That trembles vnder his deuouring Pawes:
And ſo he walkes, insulting o’re his Prey,
And ſo he comes, to rend his Limbes asunder.
Ah gentle Clifford, kill me with thy Sword,
And not with ſuch a cruell threatning Looke.
Sweet Clifford heare me ſpeake, before I dye:
I am too meane a ſubiect for thy Wrath,
Be thou reueng’d on men, and let me liue.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: In vaine thou ſpeak'st, poore Boy:
My Fathers blood hath ſtopt the paſſage
Where thy words ſhould enter.

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: Then let my Fathers blood open it againe,
He is a man, and Clifford cope with him.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Had I thy Brethren here, their liues and thine
Were not reuenge ſufficient for me:
No, if I digg’d vp thy fore-fathers Graues,
And hung their rotten Coffins vp in Chaynes,
It could not ſlake mine ire, nor ease my heart.
The ſight of any of the House of Yorke,
Is as a furie to torment my Soule:
And till I root out their accursed Line,
And leaue not one aliue, I liue in Hell.
Therefore—

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: Oh let me pray, before I take my death:
To thee I pray; ſweet Clifford pitty me.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Such pitty as my Rapiers point affords.

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: I neuer did thee harme: why wilt thou ſlay me?

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Thy Father hath.

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: But 'twas ere I was borne.
Thou hast one Sonne, for his ſake pitty me,
Least in reuenge thereof, ſith God is iust,
He be as miserably ſlaine as I.
Ah, let me liue in Prison all my dayes,
And when I giue occasion of offence,
Then let me dye, for now thou hast no cause.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: No cause? thy Father ſlew my Father: there-fore dye.

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: Dij faciant laudis ſumma ſit ista tuae.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Plantagenet, I come Plantagenet:
And this thy Sonnes blood cleauing to my Blade,
Shall rust vpon my Weapon, till thy blood
Congeal’d with this, doe make me wipe off both.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter Richard, Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: The Army of the Queene hath got the field: My Vnckles both are ſlaine, in rescuing me; And all my followers, to the eager fœ Turne back, and flye, like Ships before the Winde, Or Lambes pursu’d by hunger-starued Wolues. My Sonnes, God knowes what hath bechanced them: But this I know, they haue demean’d themselues Like men borne to Renowne, by Life or Death. Three times did Richard make a Lane to me, And thrice cry’de, Courage Father, fight it out: And full as oft came Edward to my ſide, With Purple Faulchion, painted to the Hilt, In blood of those that had encountred him: And when the hardyest Warriors did retyre, Richard cry’de, Charge, and giue no foot of ground, And cry’de, A Crowne, or else a glorious Tombe, A Scepter, or an Earthly Sepulchre. With this we charg’d againe: but out alas, We bodg’d againe, as I haue ſeene a Swan With bootleſſe labour ſwimme against the Tyde, And ſpend her ſtrength with ouer-matching Waues. A ſhort Alarum within. Ah hearke, the fatall followers doe pursue, And I am faint, and cannot flye their furie: And were I ſtrong, I would not ſhunne their furie, The Sands are numbred, that makes vp my Life, Here must I ſtay, and here my Life must end. Enter the Queene, Clifford, Northumberland, the young Prince, and Souldiers Come bloody Clifford, rough Northumberland, I dare your quenchleſſe furie to more rage: I am your Butt, and I abide your Shot.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Yeeld to our mercy, proud Plantagenet.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: I, to ſuch mercy, as his ruthleſſe Arme
With downe-right payment, ſhew’d vnto my Father.
Now Phaeton hath tumbled from his Carre,
And made an Euening at the Noone-tide Prick.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: My ashes, as the Phœnix, may bring forth
A Bird, that will reuenge vpon you all:
And in that hope, I throw mine eyes to Heauen,
Scorning what ere you can afflict me with.
Why come you not? what, multitudes, and feare?

speech.speaker: Cliff.
speech.line: So Cowards fight, when they can flye no further,
So Doues doe peck the Faulcons piercing Tallons,
So desperate Theeues, all hopeleſſe of their Liues,
Breathe out Inuectiues 'gainst the Officers.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Oh Clifford, but bethinke thee once againe,
And in thy thought ore-run my former time:
And if thou canst, for blushing, view this face,
And bite thy tongue, that ſlanders him with Cowardice,
Whose frowne hath made thee faint and flye ere this.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: I will not bandie with thee word for word,
But buckler with thee blowes twice two for one.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Hold valiant Clifford, for a thousand causes
I would prolong a while the Traytors Life:
Wrath makes him deafe; ſpeake thou Northumberland.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Hold Clifford, doe not honor him ſo much,
To prick thy finger, though to wound his heart.
What valour were it, when a Curre doth grinne,
For one to thrust his Hand betweene his Teeth,
When he might ſpurne him with his Foot away?
It is Warres prize, to take all Vantages,
And tenne to one, is no impeach of Valour.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: I, I, ſo ſtriues the Woodcocke with the
Gynne.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: So doth the Connie ſtruggle in the
Net.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: So triumph Theeues vpon their conquer’d Booty,
So True men yeeld with Robbers, ſo o’re-matcht.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: What would your Grace haue done vnto him now?

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Braue Warriors, Clifford and Northumberland,
Come make him ſtand vpon this Mole-hill here,
That raught at Mountaines with out-stretched Armes,
Yet parted but the ſhadow with his Hand.
What, was it you that would be Englands King?
Was't you that reuell’d in our Parliament,
And made a Preachment of your high Descent?
Where are your Meſſe of Sonnes, to back you now?
The wanton Edward, and the lustie George?
And where's that valiant Crook-back Prodigie,
Dickie, your Boy, that with his grumbling voyce
Was wont to cheare his Dad in Mutinies?
Or with the rest, where is your Darling, Rutland?
Looke Yorke, I ſtayn’d this Napkin with the blood
That valiant Clifford, with his Rapiers point,
Made iſſue from the Bosome of the Boy:
And if thine eyes can water for his death,
I giue thee this to drie thy Cheekes withall.
Alas poore Yorke, but that I hate thee deadly,
I ſhould lament thy miserable ſtate.
I prythee grieue, to make me merry, Yorke.
What, hath thy fierie heart ſo parcht thine entrayles,
That not a Teare can fall, for Rutlands death?
Why art thou patient, man? thou ſhould'st be mad:
And I, to make thee mad, doe mock thee thus.
Stampe, raue, and fret, that I may ſing and dance.
Thou would'st be fee’d, I ſee, to make me ſport:
Yorke cannot ſpeake, vnleſſe he weare a Crowne.
A Crowne for Yorke; and Lords, bow lowe to him:
Hold you his hands, whilest I doe ſet it on.
I marry Sir, now lookes he like a King:
I, this is he that tooke King Henries Chaire,
And this is he was his adopted Heire.
But how is it, that great Plantagenet
Is crown’d ſo ſoone, and broke his ſolemne Oath?
As I bethinke me, you ſhould not be King,
Till our King Henry had ſhooke hands with Death.
And will you pale your head in Henries Glory,
And rob his Temples of the Diademe,
Now in his Life, against your holy Oath?
Oh ‘tis a fault too too vnpardonable.
Off with the Crowne; and with the Crowne, his Head,
And whilest we breathe, take time to doe him dead.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: That is my Office, for my Fathers ſake.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Nay ſtay, let's heare the Orizons hee makes.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Shee-Wolfe of France,
But worse then Wolues of France,
Whose Tongue more poysons then the Adders Tooth:
How ill-beseeming is it in thy Sex,
To triumph like an Amazonian Trull,
Vpon their Wœs, whom Fortune captiuates?
But that thy Face is Vizard-like, vnchanging,
Made impudent with vse of euill deedes.
I would aſſay, prowd Queene, to make thee blush.
To tell thee whence thou cam'st, of whom deriu’d,
Were ſhame enough, to ſhame thee,
Wert thou not ſhameleſſe.
Thy Father beares the type of King of Naples,
Of both the Sicils, and Ierusalem,
Yet not ſo wealthie as an English Yeoman.
Hath that poore Monarch taught thee to insult?
It needes not, nor it bootes thee not, prowd Queene,
Vnleſſe the Adage must be verify’d,
That Beggers mounted, runne their Horse to death.
‘Tis Beautie that doth oft make Women prowd,
But God he knowes, thy ſhare thereof is ſmall.
‘Tis Vertue, that doth make them mo’t admir’d,
The contrary, doth make thee wondred at.
‘Tis Gouernment that makes them ſeeme Diuine,
The want thereof, makes thee abhominable.
Thou art as opposite to euery good,
As the Antipodes are vnto vs,
Or as the South to the Septentrion.
Oh Tygres Heart, wrapt in a Womans Hide,
How could'st thou drayne the Life-blood of the Child,
To bid the Father wipe his eyes withall,
And yet be ſeene to beare a Womans face?
Women are ſoft, milde, pittifull, and flexible;
Thou, ſterne, obdurate, flintie, rough, remorseleſſe.
Bidst thou me rage? why now thou hast thy wish.
Would'st haue me weepe? why now thou hast thy will.
For raging Wind blowes vp inceſſant ſhowers,
And when the Rage allayes, the Raine begins.
These Teares are my ſweet Rutlands Obsequies,
And euery drop cryes vengeance for his death,
'Gainst thee fell Clifford, and thee false French-woman.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Beshrew me, but his paſſions moues me ſo,
That hardly can I check my eyes from Teares.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: That Face of his,
The hungry Caniballs would not haue toucht,
Would not haue ſtayn’d with blood:
But you are more inhumane, more inexorable,
Oh, tenne times more then Tygers of Hyrcania.
See, ruthleſſe Queene, a hapleſſe Fathers Teares:
This Cloth thou dipd'st in blood of my ſweet Boy,
And I with Teares doe wash the blood away.
Keepe thou the Napkin, and goe boast of this,
And if thou tell'st the heauie ſtorie right,
Vpon my Soule, the hearers will ſhed Teares:
Yea, euen my Fœs will ſhed fast-falling Teares,
And ſay, Alas, it was a pittious deed.
There, take the Crowne, and with the Crowne, my Curse,
And in thy need, ſuch comfort come to thee,
As now I reape at thy too cruell hand.
Hard-hearted Clifford, take me from the World,
My Soule to Heauen, my Blood vpon your Heads.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Had he been ſlaughter-man to all my Kinne,
I ſhould not for my Life but weepe with him,
To ſee how inly Sorrow gripes his Soule.

speech.speaker: Queen.
speech.line: What, weeping ripe, my Lord Northumberland?
Thinke but vpon the wrong he did vs all,
And that will quickly drie thy melting Teares.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Heere's for my Oath, heere's for my Fathers
Death.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: And heere's to right our gentle-hearted
King.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Open thy Gate of Mercy, gracious God,
My Soule flyes through these wounds, to ſeeke out thee.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Off with his Head, and ſet it on Yorke Gates, So Yorke may ouer-looke the Towne of Yorke.

scene.stagedir: A March. Enter Edward, Richard, and their power

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: I wonder how our Princely Father ſcap't:
Or whether he be ſcap't away, or no,
From Cliffords and Northumberlands pursuit?
Had he been ta'ne, we ſhould haue heard the newes;
Had he beene ſlaine, we ſhould haue heard the newes:
Or had he ſcap't, me thinkes we ſhould haue heard
The happy tidings of his good escape.
How fares my Brother? why is he ſo ſad?

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: I cannot ioy, vntill I be resolu’d
Where our right valiant Father is become.
I ſaw him in the Battaile range about,
And watcht him how he ſingled Clifford forth.
Me thought he bore him in the thickest troupe,
As doth a Lyon in a Heard of Neat,
Or as a Beare encompaſſ’d round with Dogges:
Who hauing pincht a few, and made them cry,
The rest ſtand all aloofe, and barke at him.
So far’d our Father with his Enemies,
So fled his Enemies my Warlike Father:
Me thinkes ‘tis prize enough to be his Sonne.
See how the Morning opes her golden Gates,
And takes her farwell of the glorious Sunne.
How well resembles it the prime of Youth,
Trimm’d like a Yonker, prauncing to his Loue?

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Dazle mine eyes, or doe I ſee three Sunnes?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Three glorious Sunnes, each one a perfect Sunne,
Not ſeperated with the racking Clouds,
But ſeuer’d in a pale cleare-shining Skye.
See, ſee, they ioyne, embrace, and ſeeme to kiſſe,
As if they vow’d ſome League inuiolable.
Now are they but one Lampe, one Light, one Sunne:
In this, the Heauen figures ſome euent.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: ‘Tis wondrous ſtrange,
The like yet neuer heard of.
I thinke it cites vs (Brother) to the field,
That wee, the Sonnes of braue Plantagenet,
Each one alreadie blazing by our meedes,
Should notwithstanding ioyne our Lights together,
And ouer-shine the Earth, as this the World.
What ere it bodes, hence-forward will I beare
Vpon my Targuet three faire ſhining Sunnes.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Nay, beare three Daughters:
By your leaue, I ſpeake it,
You loue the Breeder better then the Male.
But what art thou, whose heauie Lookes fore-tell
Some dreadfull ſtory hanging on thy Tongue?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Ah, one that was a wofull looker on,
When as the Noble Duke of Yorke was ſlaine,
Your Princely Father, and my louing Lord.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: Oh ſpeake no more, for I haue heard too much.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Say how he dy’de, for I will heare it all.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Enuironed he was with many fœs,
And ſtood against them, as the hope of Troy
Against the Greekes, that would haue entred Troy.
But Hercules himselfe must yeeld to oddes:
And many ſtroakes, though with a little Axe,
Hewes downe and fells the hardest-tymber’d Oake.
By many hands your Father was ſubdu’d,
But onely ſlaught'red by the irefull Arme
Of vn-relenting Clifford, and the Queene:
Who crown’d the gracious Duke in high despight,
Laugh’d in his face: and when with griefe he wept,
The ruthleſſe Queene gaue him, to dry his Cheekes,
A Napkin, ſteeped in the harmeleſſe blood
Of ſweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford ſlaine:
And after many ſcornes, many foule taunts,
They tooke his Head, and on the Gates of Yorke
They ſet the ſame, and there it doth remaine,
The ſaddest ſpectacle that ere I view’d.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: Sweet Duke of Yorke, our Prop to leane vpon,
Now thou art gone, wee haue no Staffe, no Stay.
Oh Clifford, boyst'rous Clifford, thou hast ſlaine
The flowre of Europe, for his Cheualrie,
And trecherously hast thou vanquisht him,
For hand to hand he would haue vanquisht thee.
Now my Soules Pallace is become a Prison:
Ah, would ſhe breake from hence, that this my body
Might in the ground be closed vp in rest:
For neuer henceforth ſhall I ioy againe:
Neuer, oh neuer ſhall I ſee more ioy.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I cannot weepe: for all my bodies moysture
Scarse ſerues to quench my Furnace-burning hart:
Nor can my tongue vnloade my hearts great burthen,
For ſelfe-ſame winde that I ſhould ſpeake withall,
Is kindling coales that fires all my brest,
And burnes me vp with flames, that tears would quench.
To weepe, is to make leſſe the depth of greefe:
Teares then for Babes; Blowes, and Reuenge for mee.
Richard, I beare thy name, Ile venge thy death,
Or dye renowned by attempting it.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: His name that valiant Duke hath left with thee:
His Dukedome, and his Chaire with me is left.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Nay, if thou be that Princely Eagles Bird, Shew thy descent by gazing 'gainst the Sunne: For Chaire and Dukedome, Throne and Kingdome ſay, Either that is thine, or else thou wer't not his.

scene.stagedir: March. Enter Warwicke, Marqueſſe Mountacute, and their Army

speech.speaker: Warwick.
speech.line: How now faire Lords? What faire? What newes abroad?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Great Lord of Warwicke, if we ſhould recompt
Our balefull newes, and at each words deliuerance
Stab Poniards in our flesh, till all were told,
The words would adde more anguish then the wounds.
O valiant Lord, the Duke of Yorke is ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: O Warwicke, Warwicke, that Plantagenet
Which held thee deerely, as his Soules Redemption,
Is by the ſterne Lord Clifford done to death.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Ten dayes ago, I drown’d these newes in teares.
And now to adde more measure to your wœs,
I come to tell you things ſith then befalne.
After the bloody Fray at Wakefield fought,
Where your braue Father breath’d his latest gaspe,
Tydings, as ſwiftly as the Postes could runne,
Were brought me of your Loſſe, and his Depart.
I then in London, keeper of the King,
Muster’d my Soldiers, gathered flockes of Friends,
Marcht toward S[aint]. Albons, to intercept the Queene,
Bearing the King in my behalfe along:
For by my Scouts, I was aduertised
That ſhe was comming with a full intent
To dash our late Decree in Parliament,
Touching King Henries Oath, and your Succeſſion:
Short Tale to make, we at S[aint]. Albons met,
Our Battailes ioyn’d, and both ſides fiercely fought:
But whether 'twas the coldneſſe of the King,
Who look’d full gently on his warlike Queene,
That robb’d my Soldiers of their heated Spleene.
Or whether 'twas report of her ſucceſſe,
Or more then common feare of Cliffords Rigour,
Who thunders to his Captiues, Blood and Death,
I cannot iudge: but to conclude with truth,
Their Weapons like to Lightning, came and went:
Our Souldiers like the Night-Owles lazie flight,
Or like a lazie Thresher with a Flaile,
Fell gently downe, as if they ſtrucke their Friends.
I cheer’d them vp with iustice of our Cause,
With promise of high pay, and great Rewards:
But all in vaine, they had no heart to fight,
And we (in them) no hope to win the day,
So that we fled: the King vnto the Queene,
Lord George, your Brother, Norfolke, and my Selfe,
In haste, post haste, are come to ioyne with you:
For in the Marches heere we heard you were,
Making another Head, to fight againe.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Where is the Duke of Norfolke, gentle Warwick?
And when came George from Burgundy to England?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Some ſix miles off the Duke is with the Soldiers,
And for your Brother he was lately ſent
From your kinde Aunt Dutcheſſe of Burgundie,
With ayde of Souldiers to this needfull Warre.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: 'Twas oddes belike, when valiant Warwick fled;
Oft haue I heard his praises in Pursuite,
But ne're till now, his Scandall of Retire.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Nor now my Scandall Richard, dost thou heare:
For thou ſhalt know this ſtrong right hand of mine,
Can plucke the Diadem from faint Henries head,
And wring the awefull Scepter from his Fist,
Were he as famous, and as bold in Warre,
As he is fam’d for Mildneſſe, Peace, and Prayer.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I know it well Lord Warwick, blame me not,
‘Tis loue I beare thy glories make me ſpeake:
But in this troublous time, what’s to be done?
Shall we go throw away our Coates of Steele,
And wrap our bodies in blacke mourning Gownes,
Numb'ring our Aue-Maries with our Beads?
Or ſhall we on the Helmets of our Fœs
Tell our Deuotion with reuengefull Armes?
If for the last, ſay I, and to it Lords.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Why therefore Warwick came to ſeek you out,
And therefore comes my Brother Mountague:
Attend me Lords, the proud insulting Queene,
With Clifford, and the haught Northumberland,
And of their Feather, many moe proud Birds,
Haue wrought the easie-melting King, like Wax.
He ſwore consent to your Succeſſion,
His Oath enrolled in the Parliament.
And now to London all the crew are gone,
To frustrate both his Oath, and what beside
May make against the house of Lancaster.
Their power (I thinke) is thirty thousand ſtrong:
Now, if the helpe of Norfolke, and my ſelfe,
With all the Friends that thou braue Earle of March,
Among'st the louing Welshmen can'st procure,
Will but amount to fiue and twenty thousand,
Why Via, to London will we march,
And once againe, bestride our foaming Steeds,
And once againe cry Charge vpon our Fœs,
But neuer once againe turne backe and flye.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, now me thinks I heare great Warwick ſpeak;
Ne're may he liue to ſee a Sun-shine day,
That cries Retire, if Warwicke bid him ſtay.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Lord Warwicke, on thy ſhoulder will I leane,
And when thou failst (as God forbid the houre)
Must Edward fall, which perill heauen forefend.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: No longer Earle of March, but Duke of Yorke:
The next degree, is Englands Royall Throne:
For King of England ſhalt thou be proclaim’d
In euery Burrough as we paſſe along,
And he that throwes not vp his cap for ioy,
Shall for the Fault make forfeit of his head.
King Edward, valiant Richard Mountague:
Stay we no longer, dreaming of Renowne.
But ſound the Trumpets, and about our Taske.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Then Clifford, were thy heart as hard as Steele,
As thou hast ſhewne it flintie by thy deeds,
I come to pierce it, or to giue thee mine.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Then ſtrike vp Drums, God and S[aint]. George for vs.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: How now? what newes?

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: The Duke of Norfolke ſends you word by me,
The Queene is comming with a puiſſant Hoast,
And craues your company, for ſpeedy counsell.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Why then it ſorts, braue Warriors, let's away.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the King, the Queene, Clifford, Northum-[berland] and Yong Prince, with Drumme and Trumpettes

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Welcome my Lord, to this braue town of Yorke,
Yonders the head of that Arch-enemy,
That ſought to be incompast with your Crowne.
Doth not the obiect cheere your heart, my Lord.

speech.speaker: K.
speech.line: I, as the rockes cheare them that feare their wrack,
To ſee this ſight, it irkes my very ſoule:
With-hold reuenge (deere God) ‘tis not my fault,
Nor wittingly haue I infring’d my Vow.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: My gracious Liege, this too much lenity
And harmfull pitty must be layd aside:
To whom do Lyons cast their gentle Lookes?
Not to the Beast, that would vsurpe their Den.
Whose hand is that the Forrest Beare doth licke?
Not his that ſpoyles her yong before her face.
Who ſcapes the lurking Serpents mortall ſting?
Not he that ſets his foot vpon her backe.
The ſmallest Worme will turne, being troden on,
And Doues will pecke in ſafegard of their Brood.
Ambitious Yorke, did leuell at thy Crowne,
Thou ſmiling, while he knit his angry browes.
He but a Duke, would haue his Sonne a King,
And raise his iſſue like a louing Sire.
Thou being a King, blest with a goodly ſonne,
Did'st yeeld consent to disinherit him:
Which argued thee a mo’t vnlouing Father.
Vnreasonable Creatures feed their young,
And though mans face be fearefull to their eyes,
Yet in protection of their tender ones,
Who hath not ſeene them euen with those wings,
Which ſometime they haue vs’d with fearfull flight,
Make warre with him that climb’d vnto their nest,
Offering their owne liues in their yongs defence?
For ſhame, my Liege, make them your President:
Were it not pitty that this goodly Boy
Should loose his Birth-right by his Fathers fault,
And long heereafter ſay vnto his childe,
What my great Grandfather, and Grandsire got,
My careleſſe Father fondly gaue away.
Ah, what a ſhame were this? Looke on the Boy,
And let his manly face, which promiseth
Succeſſefull Fortune ſteele thy melting heart,
To hold thine owne, and leaue thine owne with him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Full well hath Clifford plaid the Orator,
Inferring arguments of mighty force:
But Clifford tell me, did'st thou neuer heare,
That things ill got, had euer bad ſucceſſe.
And happy alwayes was it for that Sonne,
Whose Father for his hoording went to hell:
Ile leaue my Sonne my Vertuous deeds behinde,
And would my Father had left me no more:
For all the rest is held at ſuch a Rate,
As brings a thousand fold more care to keepe,
Then in poſſeſſion any iot of pleasure.
Ah Cosin Yorke, would thy best Friends did know,
How it doth greeue me that thy head is heere.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: My Lord cheere vp your ſpirits, our fœs are nye,
And this ſoft courage makes your Followers faint:
You promist Knighthood to our forward ſonne,
Vnsheath your ſword, and dub him presently.
Edward, kneele downe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Edward Plantagenet, arise a Knight,
And learne this Leſſon; Draw thy Sword in right.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: My gracious Father, by your Kingly leaue,
Ile draw it as Apparant to the Crowne,
And in that quarrell, vse it to the death.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Why that is ſpoken like a toward Prince.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Royall Commanders, be in readineſſe,
For with a Band of thirty thousand men,
Comes Warwicke backing of the Duke of Yorke,
And in the Townes as they do march along,
Proclaimes him King, and many flye to him,
Darraigne your battell, for they are at hand.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: I would your Highneſſe would depart the field,
The Queene hath best ſucceſſe when you are absent.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: I good my Lord, and leaue vs to our Fortune.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why, that’s my fortune too, therefore Ile ſtay.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Be it with resolution then to fight.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: My Royall Father, cheere these Noble Lords,
And hearten those that fight in your defence:
Vnsheath your Sword, good Father: Cry S[aint]. George.

scene.stagedir: March. Enter Edward, Warwicke, Richard, Clarence, Norfolke, Mountague, and Soldiers

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now periur’d Henry, wilt thou kneel for grace?
And ſet thy Diadem vpon my head?
Or bide the mortall Fortune of the field.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Go rate thy Minions, proud insulting Boy,
Becomes it thee to be thus bold in termes,
Before thy Soueraigne, and thy lawfull King?

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: I am his King, and he ſhould bow his knee:
I was adopted Heire by his consent.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Since when, his Oath is broke: for as I heare,
You that are King, though he do weare the Crowne,
Haue caus’d him by new Act of Parliament,
To blot out me, and put his owne Sonne in.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: And reason too,
Who ſhould ſucceede the Father, but the Sonne.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Are you there Butcher? O, I cannot ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: I Crooke-back, here I ſtand to anſwer thee,
Or any he, the proudest of thy ſort.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: 'Twas you that kill’d yong Rutland, was it not?

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: I, and old Yorke, and yet not ſatisfied.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: For Gods ſake Lords giue ſignall to the fight.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: What ſay'st thou Henry,
Wilt thou yeeld the Crowne?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Why how now long-tongu’d Warwicke, dare you ſpeak?
When you and I, met at S[aint]. Albons last,
Your legges did better ſeruice then your hands.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Then 'twas my turne to fly, and now ‘tis thine:

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: You ſaid ſo much before, and yet you fled.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: 'Twas not your valor Clifford droue me thence.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: No, nor your manhood that durst make you ſtay.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Northumberland, I hold thee reuerently,
Breake off the parley, for ſcarse I can refraine
The execution of my big-swolne heart
Vpon that Clifford, that cruell Child-killer.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: I ſlew thy Father, cal'st thou him a Child?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I like a Dastard, and a treacherous Coward,
As thou didd'st kill our tender Brother Rutland,
But ere Sunset, Ile make thee curse the deed.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Haue done with words (my Lords) and heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Defie them then, or els hold close thy lips.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I prythee giue no limits to my Tongue,
I am a King, and priuiledg’d to ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: My Liege, the wound that bred this meeting here,
Cannot be cur’d by Words, therefore be ſtill.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Then Executioner vnsheath thy ſword:
By him that made vs all, I am resolu’d,
That Cliffords Manhood, lyes vpon his tongue.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Say Henry, ſhall I haue my right, or no:
A thousand men haue broke their Fasts to day,
That ne're ſhall dine, vnleſſe thou yeeld the Crowne.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: If thou deny, their Blood vpon thy head,
For Yorke in iustice put's his Armour on.

speech.speaker: Pr.Ed.
speech.line: If that be right, which Warwick ſaies is right,
There is no wrong, but euery thing is right.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Who euer got thee, there thy Mother ſtands,
For well I wot, thou hast thy Mothers tongue.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: But thou art neyther like thy Sire nor Damme,
But like a foule mishapen Stygmaticke,
Mark’d by the Destinies to be auoided,
As venome Toades, or Lizards dreadfull ſtings.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Iron of Naples, hid with English gilt,
Whose Father beares the Title of a King,
(As if a Channell ſhould be call’d the Sea)
Sham'st thou not, knowing whence thou art extraught,
To let thy tongue detect thy base-borne heart.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: A wispe of ſtraw were worth a thousand Crowns,
To make this ſhameleſſe Callet know her ſelfe:
Helen of Greece was fayrer farre then thou,
Although thy Husband may be Menelaus;
And ne're was Agamemnons Brother wrong’d
By that false Woman, as this King by thee.
His Father reuel’d in the heart of France,
And tam’d the King, and made the Dolphin ſtoope:
And had he match’d according to his State,
He might haue kept that glory to this day.
But when he tooke a begger to his bed,
And grac’d thy poore Sire with his Bridall day,
Euen then that Sun-shine brew’d a ſhowre for him,
That washt his Fathers fortunes forth of France,
And heap’d ſedition on his Crowne at home:
For what hath broach’d this tumult but thy Pride?
Had'st thou bene meeke, our Title ſtill had ſlept,
And we in pitty of the Gentle King,
Had ſlipt our Claime, vntill another Age.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: But when we ſaw, our Sunshine made thy Spring,
And that thy Summer bred vs no increase,
We ſet the Axe to thy vsurping Roote:
And though the edge hath ſomething hit our ſelues,
Yet know thou, ſince we haue begun to ſtrike,
Wee'l neuer leaue, till we haue hewne thee downe,
Or bath’d thy growing, with our heated bloods.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: And in this resolution, I defie thee,
Not willing any longer Conference,
Since thou denied'st the gentle King to ſpeake.
Sound Trumpets, let our bloody Colours waue,
And either Victorie, or else a Graue.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Stay Edward.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: No wrangling Woman, wee'l no longer ſtay,
These words will cost ten thousand liues this day.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Fore-spent with Toile, as Runners with a Race,
I lay me downe a little while to breath:
For ſtrokes receiu’d, and many blowes repaid,
Haue robb’d my ſtrong knit ſinewes of their ſtrength,
And ſpight of ſpight, needs must I rest a-while.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Smile gentle heauen, or ſtrike vngentle death,
For this world frownes, and Edwards Sunne is clowded.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: How now my Lord, what happe? what hope of good?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Our hap is loſſe, our hope but ſad dispaire,
Our rankes are broke, and ruine followes vs.
What counsaile giue you? whether ſhall we flye?

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Bootleſſe is flight, they follow vs with Wings,
And weake we are, and cannot ſhun pursuite.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ah Warwicke, why hast y withdrawn thy ſelfe?
Thy Brothers blood the thirsty earth hath drunk,
Broach’d with the Steely point of Cliffords Launce:
And in the very pangs of death, he cryde,
Like to a dismall Clangor heard from farre,
Warwicke, reuenge; Brother, reuenge my death.
So vnderneath the belly of their Steeds,
That ſtain’d their Fetlockes in his ſmoaking blood,
The Noble Gentleman gaue vp the ghoſt.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Then let the earth be drunken with our blood:
Ile kill my Horse, because I will not flye:
Why ſtand we like ſoft-hearted women heere,
Wayling our loſſes, whiles the Fœ doth Rage,
And looke vpon, as if the Tragedie
Were plaid in iest, by counterfetting Actors.
Heere on my knee, I vow to God aboue,
Ile neuer pawse againe, neuer ſtand ſtill,
Till either death hath clos’d these eyes of mine,
Or Fortune giuen me measure of Reuenge.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Oh Warwicke, I do bend my knee with thine,
And in this vow do chaine my ſoule to thine:
And ere my knee rise from the Earths cold face,
I throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to thee,
Thou ſetter vp, and plucker downe of Kings:
Beseeching thee (if with thy will it ſtands)
That to my Fœs this body must be prey,
Yet that thy brazen gates of heauen may ope,
And giue ſweet paſſage to my ſinfull ſoule.
Now Lords, take leaue vntill we meete againe,
Where ere it be, in heauen, or in earth.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Brother,
Giue me thy hand, and gentle Warwicke,
Let me imbrace thee in my weary armes:
I that did neuer weepe, now melt with wo,
That Winter ſhould cut off our Spring-time ſo.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Away, away:
Once more ſweet Lords farwell.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Yet let vs altogether to our Troopes,
And giue them leaue to flye, that will not ſtay:
And call them Pillars that will ſtand to vs:
And if we thriue, promise them ſuch rewards
As Victors weare at the Olympian Games.
This may plant courage in their quailing breasts,
For yet is hope of Life and Victory:
Foreslow no longer, make we hence amaine.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Now Clifford, I haue ſingled thee alone,
Suppose this arme is for the Duke of Yorke,
And this for Rutland, both bound to reuenge,
Wer't thou inuiron’d with a Brazen wall.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Now Richard, I am with thee heere alone,
This is the hand that ſtabb’d thy Father Yorke,
And this the hand, that ſlew thy Brother Rutland,
And here's the heart, that triumphs in their death,
And cheeres these hands, that ſlew thy Sire and Brother,
To execute the like vpon thy ſelfe,
And ſo haue at thee.

scene.stagedir: They Fight, Warwicke comes, Clifford flies.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Nay Warwicke, ſingle out ſome other Chace,
For I my ſelfe will hunt this Wolfe to death.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: This battell fares like to the mornings Warre, When dying clouds contend, with growing light, What time the Shepheard blowing of his nailes, Can neither call it perfect day, nor night. Now ſwayes it this way, like a Mighty Sea, Forc’d by the Tide, to combat with the Winde: Now ſwayes it that way, like the ſelfe-ſame Sea, Forc’d to retyre by furie of the Winde. Sometime, the Flood preuailes; and than the Winde: Now, one the better: then, another best; Both tugging to be Victors, brest to brest: Yet neither Conqueror, nor Conquered. So is the equall poise of this fell Warre. Heere on this Mole-hill will I ſit me downe, To whom God will, there be the Victorie: For Margaret my Queene, and Clifford too Haue chid me from the Battell: Swearing both, They prosper best of all when I am thence. Would I were dead, if Gods good will were ſo; For what is in this world, but Greefe and Wœ. Oh God! me thinkes it were a happy life, To be no better then a homely Swaine, To ſit vpon a hill, as I do now, To carue out Dialls queintly, point by point, Thereby to ſee the Minutes how they runne: How many makes the Houre full compleate, How many Houres brings about the Day, How many Dayes will finish vp the Yeare, How many Yeares, a Mortall man may liue. When this is knowne, then to diuide the Times: So many Houres, must I tend my Flocke; So many Houres, must I take my Rest: So many Houres, must I Contemplate: So many Houres, must I Sport my ſelfe: So many Dayes, my Ewes haue bene with yong: So many weekes, ere the poore Fooles will Eane: So many yeares, ere I ſhall ſheere the Fleece: So Minutes, Houres, Dayes, Monthes, and Yeares, Past ouer to the end they were created, Would bring white haires, vnto a Quiet graue. Ah! what a life were this? How ſweet? how louely? Giues not the Hawthorne bush a ſweeter ſhade To Shepheards, looking on their ſilly Sheepe, Then doth a rich Imbroider’d Canopie To Kings, that feare their Subiects treacherie? Oh yes, it doth; a thousand fold it doth. And to conclude, the Shepherds homely Curds, His cold thinne drinke out of his Leather Bottle, His wonted ſleepe, vnder a fresh trees ſhade, All which ſecure, and ſweetly he enioyes, Is farre beyond a Princes Delicates: His Viands ſparkling in a Golden Cup, His bodie couched in a curious bed, When Care, Mistrust, and Treason waits on him.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter a Sonne that hath kill’d his Father, at one doore: and a Father that hath kill’d his Sonne at ano-ther doore.

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: Ill blowes the winde that profits no body,
This man whom hand to hand I ſlew in fight,
May be poſſeſſed with ſome ſtore of Crownes,
And I that (haply) take them from him now,
May yet (ere night) yeeld both my Life and them
To ſome man else, as this dead man doth me.
Who's this? Oh God! It is my Fathers face,
Whom in this Conflict, I (vnwares) haue kill’d:
Oh heauy times! begetting ſuch Euents.
From London, by the King was I prest forth,
My Father being the Earle of Warwickes man,
Came on the part of Yorke, prest by his Master:
And I, who at his hands receiu’d my life,
Haue by my hands, of Life bereaued him.
Pardon me God, I knew not what I did:
And pardon Father, for I knew not thee.
My Teares ſhall wipe away these bloody markes:
And no more words, till they haue flow’d their fill.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O pitteous ſpectacle! O bloody Times!
Whiles Lyons Warre, and battaile for their Dennes,
Poore harmleſſe Lambes abide their enmity.
Weepe wretched man: Ile ayde thee Teare for Teare,
And let our hearts and eyes, like Ciuill Warre,
Be blinde with teares, and break ore-charg’d with griefe

scene.stagedir: Enter Father, bearing of his Sonne.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Thou that ſo ſtoutly hath resisted me,
Giue me thy Gold, if thou hast any Gold:
For I haue bought it with an hundred blowes.
But let me ſee: Is this our Fœ-mans face?
Ah, no, no, no, it is mine onely Sonne.
Ah Boy, if any life be left in thee,
Throw vp thine eye: ſee, ſee, what ſhowres arise,
Blowne with the windie Tempest of my heart,
Vpon thy wounds, that killes mine Eye, and Heart.
O pitty God, this miserable Age!
What Stratagems? how fell? how Butcherly?
Erreoneous, mutinous, and vnnaturall,
This deadly quarrell daily doth beget?
O Boy! thy Father gaue thee life too ſoone,
And hath bereft thee of thy life too late.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Wo aboue wo: greefe, more the[n] common greefe
O that my death would ſtay these ruthfull deeds:
O pitty, pitty, gentle heauen pitty:
The Red Rose and the White are on his face,
The fatall Colours of our ſtriuing Houses:
The one, his purple Blood right well resembles,
The other his pale Cheekes (me thinkes) presenteth:
Wither one Rose, and let the other flourish:
If you contend, a thousand liues must wither.

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: How will my Mother, for a Fathers death
Take on with me, and ne're be ſatisfi’d?

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: How will my Wife, for ſlaughter of my Sonne,
Shed ſeas of Teares, and ne're be ſatisfi’d?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How will the Country, for these woful chances,
Mis-thinke the King, and not be ſatisfied?

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: Was euer ſonne, ſo rew’d a Fathers death?

speech.speaker: Fath.
speech.line: Was euer Father ſo bemoan’d his Sonne?

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Was euer King ſo greeu’d for Subiects wœ?
Much is your ſorrow; Mine, ten times ſo much.

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: Ile beare thee hence, where I may weepe my fill.

speech.speaker: Fath.
speech.line: These armes of mine ſhall be thy winding ſheet:
My heart (sweet Boy) ſhall be thy Sepulcher,
For from my heart, thine Image ne're ſhall go.
My ſighing brest, ſhall be thy Funerall bell;
And ſo obsequious will thy Father be,
Men for the loſſe of thee, hauing no more,
As Priam was for all his Valiant Sonnes,
Ile beare thee hence, and let them fight that will,
For I haue murthered where I ſhould not kill.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Sad-hearted-men, much ouergone with Care;
Heere ſits a King, more wofull then you are.

scene.stagedir: Alarums. Excursions. Enter the Queen, the Prince, and Exeter

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Fly Father, flye: for all your Friends are fled.
And Warwicke rages like a chafed Bull:
Away, for death doth hold vs in pursuite.

scene.speech: Qu. Mount you my Lord, towards Barwicke post a-maine: _ Edward and Richard like a brace of Grey-hounds, Hauing the fearfull flying Hare in ſight, With fiery eyes, ſparkling for very wrath, And bloody ſteele graspt in their yrefull hands Are at our backes, and therefore hence amaine.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: Away: for vengeance comes along with them.
Nay, ſtay not to expostulate, make ſpeed,
Or else come after, Ile away before.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Nay take me with thee, good ſweet Exeter:
Not that I feare to ſtay, but loue to go
Whether the Queene intends. Forward, away.

scene.stagedir: A lowd alarum. Enter Clifford Wounded.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Heere burnes my Candle out; I, heere it dies,
Which whiles it lasted, gaue King Henry light.
O Lancaster! I feare thy ouerthrow,
More then my Bodies parting with my Soule:
My Loue and Feare, glew’d many Friends to thee,
And now I fall. Thy tough Commixtures melts,
Impairing Henry, ſtrength'ning misproud Yorke;
And whether flye the Gnats, but to the Sunne?
And who ſhines now, but Henries Enemies?
O Phœbus! had'st thou neuer giuen consent,
That Phaeton ſhould checke thy fiery Steeds,
Thy burning Carre neuer had ſcorch’d the earth.
And Henry, had'st thou ſway’d as Kings ſhould do,
Or as thy Father, and his Father did,
Giuing no ground vnto the house of Yorke,
They neuer then had ſprung like Sommer Flyes:
I, and ten thousand in this luckleſſe Realme,
Had left no mourning Widdowes for our death,
And thou this day, had'st kept thy Chaire in peace.
For what doth cherrish Weeds, but gentle ayre?
And what makes Robbers bold, but too much lenity?
Bootleſſe are Plaints, and Cureleſſe are my Wounds:
No way to flye, no ſtrength to hold out flight:
The Fœ is mercileſſe, and will not pitty:
For at their hands I haue deseru’d no pitty.
The ayre hath got into my deadly Wounds,
And much effuse of blood, doth make me faint:
Come Yorke, and Richard, Warwicke, and the rest,
I ſtab’d your Fathers bosomes; Split my brest.

scene.stagedir: Alarum & Retreat. Enter Edward, Warwicke, Richard, and Soldiers, Montague, & Clarence

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Now breath we Lords, good fortune bids vs pause,
And ſmooth the frownes of War, with peacefull lookes:
Some Troopes pursue the bloody-minded Queene,
That led calme Henry, though he were a King,
As doth a Saile, fill’d with a fretting Gust
Command an Argosie to ſtemme the Waues.
But thinke you (Lords) that Clifford fled with them?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: No, ‘tis impoſſible he ſhould escape:
(For though before his face I ſpeake the words)
Your Brother Richard markt him for the Graue.
And wheresœre he is, hee's ſurely dead.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Whose ſoule is that which takes hir heauy leaue?
A deadly grone, like life and deaths departing.
See who it is.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: And now the Battailes ended,
If Friend or Fœ, let him be gently vsed.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Reuoke that doome of mercy, for ‘tis Clifford,
Who not contented that he lopp’d the Branch
In hewing Rutland, when his leaues put forth,
But ſet his murth'ring knife vnto the Roote,
From whence that tender ſpray did ſweetly ſpring,
I meane our Princely Father, Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: From off the gates of Yorke, fetch down y head,
Your Fathers head, which Clifford placed there:
In ſtead whereof, let this ſupply the roome,
Measure for measure, must be answered.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Bring forth that fatall Schreechowle to our house,
That nothing ſung but death, to vs and ours:
Now death ſhall ſtop his dismall threatning ſound,
And his ill-boading tongue, no more ſhall ſpeake.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I thinke his vnderstanding is bereft:
Speake Clifford, dost thou know who ſpeakes to thee?
Darke cloudy death ore-shades his beames of life,
And he nor ſees, nor heares vs, what we ſay.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: O would he did, and ſo (perhaps) he doth,
‘Tis but his policy to counterfet,
Because he would auoid ſuch bitter taunts
Which in the time of death he gaue our Father.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: If ſo thou think'st,
Vex him with eager Words.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Clifford, aske mercy, and obtaine no grace.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Clifford, repent in bootleſſe penitence.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Clifford, deuise excuses for thy faults.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: While we deuise fell Tortures for thy faults.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thou didd'st loue Yorke, and I am ſon to Yorke.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Thou pittied'st Rutland, I will pitty thee.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Where's Captaine Margaret, to fence you now?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: They mocke thee Clifford,
Sweare as thou was't wont.

speech.speaker: Ric.
speech.line: What, not an Oath? Nay then the world go's hard
When Clifford cannot ſpare his Friends an oath:
I know by that he's dead, and by my Soule,
If this right hand would buy two houres life,
That I (in all despight) might rayle at him,
This hand ſhould chop it off: & with the iſſuing Blood
Stifle the Villaine, whose vnstanched thirst
Yorke, and yong Rutland could not ſatisfie

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I, but he's dead. Of with the Traitors head,
And reare it in the place your Fathers ſtands.
And now to London with Triumphant march,
There to be crowned Englands Royall King:
From whence, ſhall Warwicke cut the Sea to France,
And aske the Ladie Bona for thy Queene:
So ſhalt thou ſinow both these Lands together,
And hauing France thy Friend, thou ſhalt not dread
The ſcattred Fœ, that hopes to rise againe:
For though they cannot greatly ſting to hurt,
Yet looke to haue them buz to offend thine eares:
First, will I ſee the Coronation,
And then to Britanny Ile croſſe the Sea,
To effect this marriage, ſo it please my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Euen as thou wilt ſweet Warwicke, let it bee:
For in thy ſhoulder do I builde my Seate;
And neuer will I vndertake the thing
Wherein thy counsaile and consent is wanting:
Richard, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester,
And George of Clarence; Warwicke as our Selfe,
Shall do, and vndo as him pleaseth best.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloster,
For Glosters Dukedome is too ominous.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Tut, that’s a foolish obseruation:
Richard, be Duke of Gloster: Now to London,
To ſee these Honors in poſſeſſion.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sinklo, and Humfrey, with Croſſe-bowes in their hands

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: Vnder this thicke growne brake, wee'l ſhrowd our ſelues:
For through this Laund anon the Deere will come,
And in this couert will we make our Stand,
Culling the principall of all the Deere.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Ile ſtay aboue the hill, ſo both may ſhoot.

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: That cannot be, the noise of thy Croſſe-bow
Will ſcarre the Heard, and ſo my ſhoot is lost:
Heere ſtand we both, and ayme we at the best:
And for the time ſhall not ſeeme tedious,
Ile tell thee what befell me on a day,
In this ſelfe-place, where now we meane to ſtand.

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: Heere comes a man, let's ſtay till he be past:

scene.stagedir: Enter the King with a Prayer booke.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: From Scotland am I ſtolne euen of pure loue,
To greet mine owne Land with my wishfull ſight:
No Harry, Harry, ‘tis no Land of thine,
Thy place is fill’d, thy Scepter wrung from thee,
Thy Balme washt off, wherewith thou was Annointed:
No bending knee will call thee Caesar now,
No humble ſuters prease to ſpeake for right:
No, not a man comes for redreſſe of thee:
For how can I helpe them, and not my ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: I, heere's a Deere, whose ſkin's a Keepers Fee:
This is the quondam King; Let's ſeize vpon him.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Let me embrace the ſower Aduersaries,
For Wise men ſay, it is the wisest course.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Why linger we? Let vs lay hands vpon him.

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: Forbeare a-while, wee'l heare a little more.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: My Queene and Son are gone to France for aid:
And (as I heare) the great Commanding Warwicke
I: thither gone, to craue the French Kings Sister
To wife for Edward. If this newes be true,
Poore Queene, and Sonne, your labour is but lost:
For Warwicke is a ſubtle Orator:
And Lewis a Prince ſoone wonne with mouing words:
By this account then, Margaret may winne him,
For ſhe's a woman to be pittied much:
Her ſighes will make a batt'ry in his brest,
Her teares will pierce into a Marble heart:
The Tyger will be milde, whiles ſhe doth mourne;
And Nero will be tainted with remorse,
To heare and ſee her plaints, her Brinish Teares.
I, but ſhee's come to begge, Warwicke to giue:
Shee on his left ſide, crauing ayde for Henrie;
He on his right, asking a wife for Edward.
Shee Weepes, and ſayes, her Henry is depos’d:
He Smiles, and ſayes, his Edward is instaul’d;
That ſhe (poore Wretch) for greefe can ſpeake no more:
Whiles Warwicke tels his Title, ſmooths the Wrong,
Inferreth arguments of mighty ſtrength,
And in conclusion winnes the King from her,
With promise of his Sister, and what else,
To ſtrengthen and ſupport King Edwards place.
O Margaret, thus 'twill be, and thou (poore ſoule)
Art then forsaken, as thou went'st forlorne.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Say, what art thou talk'st of Kings & Queens?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: More then I ſeeme, and leſſe then I was born to:
A man at least, for leſſe I ſhould not be:
And men may talke of Kings, and why not I?

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: I, but thou talk'st, as if thou wer't a King.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why ſo I am (in Minde) and that’s enough.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: But if thou be a King, where is thy Crowne?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My Crowne is in my heart, not on my head:
Not deck’d with Diamonds, and Indian ſtones:
Nor to be ſeene: my Crowne, is call’d Content,
A Crowne it is, that ſildome Kings enioy.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Well, if you be a King crown’d with Content,
Your Crowne Content, and you, must be contented
To go along with vs. For (as we thinke)
You are the king King Edward hath depos’d:
And we his ſubiects, ſworne in all Allegeance,
Will apprehend you, as his Enemie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But did you neuer ſweare, and breake an Oath.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: No, neuer ſuch an Oath, nor will not now.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Where did you dwell when I was K[ing]. of England?

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Heere in this Country, where we now remaine.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I was annointed King at nine monthes old,
My Father, and my Grandfather were Kings:
And you were ſworne true Subiects vnto me:
And tell me then, haue you not broke your Oathes?

speech.speaker: Sin.
speech.line: No, for we were Subiects, but while you wer king

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why? Am I dead? Do I not breath a Man?
Ah ſimple men, you know not what you ſweare:
Looke, as I blow this Feather from my Face,
And as the Ayre blowes it to me againe,
Obeying with my winde when I do blow,
And yeelding to another, when it blowes,
Commanded alwayes by the greater gust:
Such is the lightneſſe of you, common men.
But do not breake your Oathes, for of that ſinne,
My milde intreatie ſhall not make you guiltie.
Go where you will, the king ſhall be commanded,
And be you kings, command, and Ile obey.

speech.speaker: Sinklo.
speech.line: We are true Subiects to the king,
King Edward.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: So would you be againe to Henrie,
If he were ſeated as king Edward is.

speech.speaker: Sinklo.
speech.line: We charge you in Gods name & the Kings,
To go with vs vnto the Officers.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: In Gods name lead, your Kings name be obeyd,
And what God will, that let your King performe.
And what he will, I humbly yeeld vnto.

scene.stagedir: Enter K[ing], Edward, Gloster, Clarence, Lady Gray.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Brother of Gloster, at S[aint]. Albons field
This Ladyes Husband, Sir Richard Grey, was ſlaine,
His Land then ſeiz’d on by the Conqueror,
Her ſuit is now, to repoſſeſſe those Lands,
Which wee in Iustice cannot well deny,
Because in Quarrell of the House of Yorke,
The worthy Gentleman did lose his Life.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Your Highneſſe ſhall doe well to graunt her ſuit:
It were dishonor to deny it her.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: It were no leſſe, but yet Ile make a pawse.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Yea, is it ſo:
I ſee the Lady hath a thing to graunt,
Before the King will graunt her humble ſuit.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: Hee knowes the Game, how true hee keepes the winde?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Silence.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Widow, we will consider of your ſuit,
And come ſome other time to know our minde.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Right gracious Lord, I cannot brooke delay:
May it please your Highneſſe to resolue me now,
And what your pleasure is, ſhall ſatisfie me.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I Widow? then Ile warrant you all your Lands,
And if what pleases him, ſhall pleasure you:
Fight closer, or good faith you'le catch a Blow.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: I feare her not, vnleſſe ſhe chance to fall.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: God forbid that, for hee'le take vantages.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How many Children hast thou, Widow? tell me.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: I thinke he meanes to begge a Child of her.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Nay then whip me: hee'le rather giue her two.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Three, my mo’t gracious Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: You ſhall haue foure, if you'le be rul’d by him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: 'Twere pittie they ſhould lose their Fathers
Lands.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Be pittifull, dread Lord, and graunt it then.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Lords giue vs leaue, Ile trye this Widowes wit.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, good leaue haue you, for you will haue leaue,
Till Youth take leaue, and leaue you to the Crutch.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now tell me, Madame, doe you loue your
Children?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: I, full as dearely as I loue my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And would you not doe much to doe them good?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: To doe them good, I would ſustayne ſome harme.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then get your Husbands Lands, to doe them good.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Therefore I came vnto your Maiestie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Ile tell you how these Lands are to be got.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: So ſhall you bind me to your Highneſſe ſeruice.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What ſeruice wilt thou doe me, if I giue them?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: What you command, that rests in me to doe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But you will take exceptions to my Boone.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: No, gracious Lord, except I cannot doe it.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, but thou canst doe what I meane to aske.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Why then I will doe what your Grace com-mands.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Hee plyes her hard, and much Raine weares the
Marble.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: As red as fire? nay then, her Wax must melt.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Why ſtoppes my Lord? ſhall I not heare my
Taske?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: An easie Taske, ‘tis but to loue a King.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: That's ſoone perform’d, because I am a Subiect.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why then, thy Husbands Lands I freely giue thee.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: I take my leaue with many thousand thankes.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Match is made, ſhee ſeales it with a Cursie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But ſtay thee, ‘tis the fruits of loue I meane.

speech.speaker: Wid.
