speech.line: The fruits of Loue, I meane, my louing Liege.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, but I feare me in another ſence.
What Loue, think'st thou, I ſue ſo much to get?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: My loue till death, my humble thanks, my prayers,
That loue which Vertue begges, and Vertue graunts.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: No, by my troth, I did not meane ſuch loue.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Why then you meane not, as I thought you did.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But now you partly may perceiue my minde.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: My minde will neuer graunt what I perceiue
Your Highneſſe aymes at, if I ayme aright.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: To tell thee plaine, I ayme to lye with thee.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: To tell you plaine, I had rather lye in Prison.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why then thou ſhalt not haue thy Husbands
Lands.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Why then mine Honestie ſhall be my Dower,
For by that loſſe, I will not purchase them.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Therein thou wrong'st thy Children mightily.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Herein your Highneſſe wrongs both them & me:
But mightie Lord, this merry inclination
Accords not with the ſadneſſe of my ſuit:
Please you dismiſſe me, eyther with I, or no.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, if thou wilt ſay I to my request:
No, if thou do'st ſay No to my demand.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Then No, my Lord: my ſuit is at an end.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Widow likes him not, ſhee knits her
Browes.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: Hee is the bluntest Woœr in Christen-dome.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Her Looks doth argue her replete with Modesty,
Her Words doth ſhew her Wit incomparable,
All her perfections challenge Soueraigntie,
One way, or other, ſhee is for a King,
And ſhee ſhall be my Loue, or else my Queene.
Say, that King Edward take thee for his Queene?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: ‘Tis better ſaid then done, my gracious Lord:
I am a ſubiect fit to ieast withall,
But farre vnfit to be a Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Sweet Widow, by my State I ſweare to thee,
I ſpeake no more then what my Soule intends,
And that is, to enioy thee for my Loue.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: And that is more then I will yeeld vnto:
I know, I am too meane to be your Queene,
And yet too good to be your Concubine.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: You cauill, Widow, I did meane my Queene.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: 'Twill grieue your Grace, my Sonnes ſhould call you Father.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: No more, then when my Daughters
Call thee Mother.
Thou art a Widow, and thou hast ſome Children,
And by Gods Mother, I being but a Batchelor,
Haue other-some. Why, ‘tis a happy thing,
To be the Father vnto many Sonnes:
Answer no more, for thou ſhalt be my Queene.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Ghostly Father now hath done his Shrift.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: When hee was made a Shriuer, 'twas for ſhift.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Brothers, you muse what Chat wee two haue had.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Widow likes it not, for ſhee lookes very ſad.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: You'ld thinke it ſtrange, if I ſhould marrie her.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: To who, my Lord?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why Clarence, to my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: That would be tenne dayes wonder at the least.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: That's a day longer then a Wonder lasts.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: By ſo much is the Wonder in extremes.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Well, ieast on Brothers: I can tell you both,
Her ſuit is graunted for her Husbands Lands.

speech.speaker: Nob.
speech.line: My gracious Lord, Henry your Fœ is taken,
And brought your Prisoner to your Pallace Gate.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: See that he be conuey’d vnto the Tower:
And goe wee Brothers to the man that tooke him,
To question of his apprehension.
Widow goe you along: Lords vse her honourable.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, Edward will vse Women honourably:
Would he were wasted, Marrow, Bones, and all,
That from his Loynes no hopefull Branch may ſpring,
To croſſe me from the Golden time I looke for:
And yet, betweene my Soules desire, and me,
The lustfull Edwards Title buryed,
Is Clarence, Henry, and his Sonne young Edward,
And all the vnlook’d-for Iſſue of their Bodies,
To take their Roomes, ere I can place my ſelfe:
A cold premeditation for my purpose.
Why then I doe but dreame on Soueraigntie,
Like one that ſtands vpon a Promontorie,
And ſpyes a farre-off ſhore, where hee would tread,
Wishing his foot were equall with his eye,
And chides the Sea, that ſunders him from thence,
Saying, hee'le lade it dry, to haue his way:
So doe I wish the Crowne, being ſo farre off,
And ſo I chide the meanes that keepes me from it,
And ſo (I ſay) Ile cut the Causes off,
Flattering me with impoſſibilities:
My Eyes too quicke, my Heart o’re-weenes too much,
Vnleſſe my Hand and Strength could equall them.
Well, ſay there is no Kingdome then for Richard:
What other Pleasure can the World affoord?
Ile make my Heauen in a Ladies Lappe,
And decke my Body in gay Ornaments,
And 'witch ſweet Ladies with my Words and Lookes.
Oh miserable Thought! and more vnlikely,
Then to accomplish twentie Golden Crownes.
Why Loue forswore me in my Mothers Wombe:
And for I ſhould not deale in her ſoft Lawes,
Shee did corrupt frayle Nature with ſome Bribe,
To ſhrinke mine Arme vp like a wither’d Shrub,
To make an enuious Mountaine on my Back,
Where ſits Deformitie to mocke my Body;
To ſhape my Legges of an vnequall ſize,
To dis-proportion me in euery part:
Like to a Chaos, or an vn-lick’d Beare-whelpe,
That carryes no impreſſion like the Damme.
And am I then a man to be belou’d?
Oh monstrous fault, to harbour ſuch a thought.
Then ſince this Earth affoords no Ioy to me,
But to command, to check, to o’re-beare ſuch,
As are of better Person then my ſelfe:
Ile make my Heauen, to dreame vpon the Crowne,
And whiles I liue, t’ account this World but Hell,
Vntill my mis-shap’d Trunke, that beares this Head,
Be round impaled with a glorious Crowne.
And yet I know not how to get the Crowne,
For many Liues ſtand betweene me and home:
And I, like one lost in a Thornie Wood,
That rents the Thornes, and is rent with the Thornes,
Seeking a way, and ſtraying from the way,
Not knowing how to finde the open Ayre,
But toyling desperately to finde it out,
Torment my ſelfe, to catch the English Crowne:
And from that torment I will free my ſelfe,
Or hew my way out with a bloody Axe.
Why I can ſmile, and murther whiles I ſmile,
And cry, Content, to that which grieues my Heart,
And wet my Cheekes with artificiall Teares,
And frame my Face to all occasions.
Ile drowne more Saylers then the Mermaid ſhall,
Ile ſlay more gazers then the Basiliske,
Ile play the Orator as well as Nestor,
Deceiue more ſlyly then Vliſſes could,
And like a Synon, take another Troy.
I can adde Colours to the Camelion,
Change ſhapes with Proteus, for aduantages,
And ſet the murtherous Macheuill to Schoole.
Can I doe this, and cannot get a Crowne?
Tut, were it farther off, Ile plucke it downe.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter Lewis the French King, his Sister Bona, his Admirall, call’d Bourbon: Prince Edward, Queene Margaret, and the Earle of Oxford. Lewis ſits, and riseth vp againe

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Faire Queene of England, worthy Margaret,
Sit downe with vs: it ill befits thy State,
And Birth, that thou ſhould'st ſtand, while Lewis doth ſit.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: No, mightie King of France: now Margaret
Must ſtrike her ſayle, and learne a while to ſerue,
Where Kings command. I was (I must confeſſe)
Great Albions Queene, in former Golden dayes:
But now mischance hath trod my Title downe,
And with dis-honor layd me on the ground,
Where I must take like Seat vnto my fortune,
And to my humble Seat conforme my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Why ſay, faire Queene, whence ſprings this deepe despaire?

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: From ſuch a cause, as fills mine eyes with teares,
And ſtops my tongue, while heart is drown’d in cares.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: What ere it be, be thou ſtill like thy ſelfe,
And ſit thee by our ſide.
Yeeld not thy necke to Fortunes yoake,
But let thy dauntleſſe minde ſtill ride in triumph,
Ouer all mischance.
Be plaine, Queene Margaret, and tell thy griefe,
It ſhall be eas’d, if France can yeeld reliefe.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: Those gracious words
Reuiue my drooping thoughts,
And giue my tongue-ty’d ſorrowes leaue to ſpeake.
Now therefore be it knowne to Noble Lewis,
That Henry, ſole poſſeſſor of my Loue,
Is, of a King, become a banisht man,
And forc’d to liue in Scotland a Forlorne;
While prowd ambitious Edward, Duke of Yorke,
Vsurpes the Regall Title, and the Seat
Of Englands true anoynted lawfull King.
This is the cause that I, poore Margaret,
With this my Sonne, Prince Edward, Henries Heire,
Am come to craue thy iust and lawfull ayde:
And if thou faile vs, all our hope is done.
Scotland hath will to helpe, but cannot helpe:
Our People, and our Peeres, are both mis-led,
Our Treasure ſeiz’d, our Souldiors put to flight,
And (as thou ſeest) our ſelues in heauie plight.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Renowned Queene,
With patience calme the Storme,
While we bethinke a meanes to breake it off.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: The more wee ſtay, the ſtronger growes our
Fœ.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: The more I ſtay, the more Ile ſuccour thee.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: O, but impatience waiteth on true ſorrow.
And ſee where comes the breeder of my ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: What's hee approacheth boldly to our pre-sence?

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: Our Earle of Warwicke, Edwards greatest
Friend.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Welcome braue Warwicke, what brings thee to France?

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: I now begins a ſecond Storme to rise,
For this is hee that moues both Winde and Tyde.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: From worthy Edward, King of Albion,
My Lord and Soueraigne, and thy vowed Friend,
I come (in Kindneſſe, and vnfayned Loue)
First, to doe greetings to thy Royall Person,
And then to craue a League of Amitie:
And lastly, to confirme that Amitie
With Nuptiall Knot, if thou vouchsafe to graunt
That vertuous Lady Bona, thy faire Sister,
To Englands King, in lawfull Marriage.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: If that goe forward, Henries hope is done.

speech.speaker: Warw
speech.line: And gracious Madame,
In our Kings behalfe,
I am commanded, with your leaue and fauor,
Humbly to kiſſe your Hand, and with my Tongue
To tell the paſſion of my Soueraignes Heart;
Where Fame, late entring at his heedfull Eares,
Hath plac’d thy Beauties Image, and thy Vertue.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: King Lewis, and Lady Bona, heare me ſpeake,
Before you anſwer Warwicke. His demand
Springs not from Edwards well-meant honeſt Loue,
But from Deceit, bred by Neceſſitie:
For how can Tyrants ſafely gouerne home,
Vnleſſe abroad they purchase great allyance?
To proue him Tyrant, this reason may ſuffice,
That Henry liueth ſtill: but were hee dead,
Yet here Prince Edward ſtands, King Henries Sonne.
Looke therefore Lewis, that by this League and Mariage
Thou draw not on thy Danger, and Dis-honor:
For though Vsurpers ſway the rule a while,
Yet Heau'ns are iust, and Time ſuppreſſeth Wrongs.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Iniurious Margaret.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: And why not Queene?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Because thy Father Henry did vsurpe,
And thou no more art Prince, then ſhee is Queene.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Then Warwicke disanulls great Iohn of Gaunt,
Which did ſubdue the greatest part of Spaine;
And after Iohn of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth,
Whose Wisdome was a Mirror to the wisest:
And after that wise Prince, Henry the Fift,
Who by his Proweſſe conquered all France:
From these, our Henry lineally descends.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Oxford, how haps it in this ſmooth discourse,
You told not, how Henry the Sixt hath lost
All that, which Henry the Fift had gotten:
Me thinkes these Peeres of France ſhould ſmile at that.
But for the rest: you tell a Pedigree
Of threescore and two yeeres, a ſilly time
To make prescription for a Kingdomes worth.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Why Warwicke, canst thou ſpeak against thy Liege,
Whom thou obeyd'st thirtie and ſix yeeres,
And not bewray thy Treason with a Blush?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Can Oxford, that did euer fence the right,
Now buckler Falsehood with a Pedigree?
For ſhame leaue Henry, and call Edward King.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Call him my King, by whose iniurious doome
My elder Brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere
Was done to death? and more then ſo, my Father,
Euen in the downe-fall of his mellow’d yeeres,
When Nature brought him to the doore of Death?
No Warwicke, no: while Life vpholds this Arme,
This Arme vpholds the House of Lancaster.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And I the House of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Queene Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford,
Vouchsafe at our request, to ſtand aside,
While I vse further conference with Warwicke.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: Heauens graunt, that Warwickes wordes be-witch him not.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: Now Warwicke, tell me euen vpon thy conscience
Is Edward your true King? for I were loth
To linke with him, that were not lawfull chosen.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Thereon I pawne my Credit, and mine Ho-nor.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: But is hee gracious in the Peoples eye?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: The more, that Henry was vnfortunate.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Then further: all diſſembling ſet aside,
Tell me for truth, the measure of his Loue
Vnto our Sister Bona.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Such it ſeemes,
As may beseeme a Monarch like himselfe.
My ſelfe haue often heard him ſay, and ſweare,
That this his Loue was an externall Plant,
Whereof the Root was fixt in Vertues ground,
The Leaues and Fruit maintain’d with Beauties Sunne,
Exempt from Enuy, but not from Disdaine,
Vnleſſe the Lady Bona quit his paine.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Now Sister, let vs heare your firme resolue.

speech.speaker: Bona.
speech.line: Your graunt, or your denyall, ſhall be mine.
Yet I confeſſe, that often ere this day,
When I haue heard your Kings desert recounted,
Mine eare hath tempted iudgement to desire.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Then Warwicke, thus:
Our Sister ſhall be Edwards.
And now forthwith ſhall Articles be drawne,
Touching the Ioynture that your King must make,
Which with her Dowrie ſhall be counter-poys’d:
Draw neere, Queene Margaret, and be a witneſſe,
That Bona ſhall be Wife to the English King.

speech.speaker: Pr.Edw.
speech.line: To Edward, but not to the English King.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: Deceitfull Warwicke, it was thy deuice,
By this alliance to make void my ſuit:
Before thy comming, Lewis was Henries friend.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: And ſtill is friend to him, and Margaret.
But if your Title to the Crowne by weake,
As may appeare by Edwards good ſucceſſe:
Then ‘tis but reason, that I be releas’d
From giuing ayde, which late I promised.
Yet ſhall you haue all kindneſſe at my hand,
That your Estate requires, and mine can yeeld.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Henry now liues in Scotland, at his ease;
Where hauing nothing, nothing can he lose.
And as for you your ſelfe (our quondam Queene)
You haue a Father able to maintaine you,
And better 'twere, you troubled him, then France.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Peace impudent, and ſhameleſſe Warwicke,
Proud ſetter vp, and puller downe of Kings,
I will not hence, till with my Talke and Teares
(Both full of Truth) I make King Lewis behold
Thy ſlye conueyance, and thy Lords false loue,
For both of you are Birds of ſelfe-ſame Feather.

speech.speaker: Lewes.
speech.line: Warwicke, this is ſome poste to vs, or thee.

speech.speaker: Post.
speech.line: My Lord Ambaſſador,
These Letters are for you. Speakes to Warwick,
Sent from your Brother Marqueſſe Montague.
These from our King, vnto your Maiesty. To Lewis. And Madam, these for you: To Margaret
From whom, I know not.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: I like it well, that our faire Queene and Mistris Smiles at her newes, while Warwicke frownes at his. Prince Ed. Nay marke how Lewis ſtampes as he were netled. I hope, all's for the best.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: Warwicke, what are thy Newes?
And yours, faire Queene.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Mine ſuch, as fill my heart with vnhop’d ioyes.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Mine full of ſorrow, and hearts discontent.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: What? has your King married the Lady Grey?
And now to ſooth your Forgery, and his,
Sends me a Paper to perswade me Patience?
Is this th’ Alliance that he ſeekes with France?
Dare he presume to ſcorne vs in this manner?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I told your Maiesty as much before:
This proueth Edwards Loue, and Warwickes honesty.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: King Lewis, I heere protest in ſight of heauen,
And by the hope I haue of heauenly bliſſe,
That I am cleere from this misdeed of Edwards;
No more my King, for he dishonors me,
But mo’t himselfe, if he could ſee his ſhame.
Did I forget, that by the House of Yorke
My Father came vntimely to his death?
Did I let paſſe th’ abuse done to my Neece?
Did I impale him with the Regall Crowne?
Did I put Henry from his Natiue Right?
And am I guerdon’d at the last, with Shame?
Shame on himselfe, for my Desert is Honor.
And to repaire my Honor lost for him,
I heere renounce him, and returne to Henry.
My Noble Queene, let former grudges paſſe,
And henceforth, I am thy true Seruitour:
I will reuenge his wrong to Lady Bona,
And replant Henry in his former ſtate.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Warwicke,
These words haue turn’d my Hate, to Loue,
And I forgiue, and quite forget old faults,
And ioy that thou becom'st King Henries Friend.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: So much his Friend, I, his Vnfained Friend,
That if King Lewis vouchsafe to furnish vs
With ſome few Bands of chosen Soldiours,
Ile vndertake to Land them on our Coast,
And force the Tyrant from his ſeat by Warre.
‘Tis not his new-made Bride ſhall ſuccour him.
And as for Clarence, as my Letters tell me,
Hee's very likely now to fall from him,
For matching more for wanton Lust, then Honor,
Or then for ſtrength and ſafety of our Country.

speech.speaker: Bona.
speech.line: Deere Brother, how ſhall Bona be reueng’d,
But by thy helpe to this distreſſed Queene?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Renowned Prince, how ſhall Poore Henry liue,
Vnleſſe thou rescue him from foule dispaire?

speech.speaker: Bona.
speech.line: My quarrel, and this English Queens, are one.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: And mine faire Lady Bona, ioynes with yours.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: And mine, with hers, and thine, and Margarets.
Therefore, at last, I firmely am resolu’d
You ſhall haue ayde.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Let me giue humble thankes for all, at once.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: Then Englands Meſſenger, returne in Poste,
And tell false Edward, thy ſupposed King,
That Lewis of France, is ſending ouer Maskers
To reuell it with him, and his new Bride.
Thou ſeest what’s past, go feare thy King withall.

speech.speaker: Bona.
speech.line: Tell him, in hope hee'l proue a widower ſhortly,
I weare the Willow Garland for his ſake.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Tell him, my mourning weeds are layde aside,
And I am ready to put Armor on.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Tell him from me, that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore Ile vn-Crowne him, er't be long.
There's thy reward, be gone.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: But Warwicke,
Thou and Oxford, with fiue thousand men
Shall croſſe the Seas, and bid false Edward battaile:
And as occasion ſerues, this Noble Queen
And Prince, ſhall follow with a fresh Supply.
Yet ere thou go, but anſwer me one doubt:
What Pledge haue we of thy firme Loyalty?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: This ſhall aſſure my constant Loyalty,
That if our Queene, and this young Prince agree,
Ile ioyne mine eldest daughter, and my Ioy,
To him forthwith, in holy Wedlocke bands.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Yes, I agree, and thanke you for your Motion.
Sonne Edward, ſhe is Faire and Vertuous,
Therefore delay not, giue thy hand to Warwicke,
And with thy hand, thy faith irreuocable,
That onely Warwickes daughter ſhall be thine.

speech.speaker: Prin.Ed.
speech.line: Yes, I accept her, for ſhe well deserues it,
And heere to pledge my Vow, I giue my hand.

scene.stagedir: He giues his hand to Warw[icke].

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: Why ſtay we now? These ſoldiers ſhalbe leuied,
And thou Lord Bourbon, our High Admirall
Shall waft them ouer with our Royall Fleete.
I long till Edward fall by Warres mischance,
For mocking Marriage with a Dame of France.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I came from Edward as Ambaſſador,
But I returne his ſworne and mortall Fœ:
Matter of Marriage was the charge he gaue me,
But dreadfull Warre ſhall anſwer his demand.
Had he none else to make a ſtale but me?
Then none but I, ſhall turne his Iest to Sorrow.
I was the Cheefe that rais’d him to the Crowne,
And Ile be Cheefe to bring him downe againe:
Not that I pitty Henries misery,
But ſeeke Reuenge on Edwards mockery.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard, Clarence, Somerset, and Mountague

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Now tell me Brother Clarence, what thinke you
Of this new Marriage with the Lady Gray?
Hath not our Brother made a worthy choice?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Alas, you know, tis farre from hence to France,
How could he ſtay till Warwicke made returne?

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: My Lords, forbeare this talke: heere comes the King.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter King Edward, Lady Grey, Penbrooke, Staf-ford, Hastings: foure ſtand on one ſide, and foure on the other

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And his well-chosen Bride.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: I minde to tell him plainly what I thinke.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now Brother of Clarence,
How like you our Choyce,
That you ſtand pensiue, as halfe malecontent?

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: As well as Lewis of France,
Or the Earle of Warwicke,
Which are ſo weake of courage, and in iudgement,
That they'le take no offence at our abuse.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Suppose they take offence without a cause:
They are but Lewis and Warwicke, I am Edward,
Your King and Warwickes, and must haue my will.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And ſhall haue your will, because our King:
Yet hastie Marriage ſeldome proueth well.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Yea, Brother Richard, are you offended too?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Not I: no:
God forbid, that I ſhould wish them ſeuer’d,
Whom God hath ioyn’d together:
I, and 'twere pittie, to ſunder them,
That yoake ſo well together.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Setting your ſkornes, and your mislike aside,
Tell me ſome reason, why the Lady Grey
Should not become my Wife, and Englands Queene?
And you too, Somerset, and Mountague,
Speake freely what you thinke.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: Then this is mine opinion:
That King Lewis becomes your Enemie,
For mocking him about the Marriage
Of the Lady Bona.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And Warwicke, doing what you gaue in charge,
Is now dis-honored by this new Marriage.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What, if both Lewis and Warwick be appeas’d,
By ſuch inuention as I can deuise?

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Yet, to haue ioyn’d with France in ſuch alliance,
Would more haue ſtrength'ned this our Commonwealth
'Gainst forraine ſtormes, then any home-bred Marriage.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: Why, knowes not Mountague, that of it ſelfe,
England is ſafe, if true within it ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: But the ſafer, when ‘tis back’d with France.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: ‘Tis better vsing France, then trusting France:
Let vs be back’d with God, and with the Seas,
Which he hath giu'n for fence impregnable,
And with their helpes, onely defend our ſelues:
In them, and in our ſelues, our ſafetie lyes.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: For this one ſpeech, Lord Hastings well deserues
To haue the Heire of the Lord Hungerford.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, what of that? it was my will, and graunt,
And for this once, my Will ſhall ſtand for Law.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And yet me thinks, your Grace hath not done well,
To giue the Heire and Daughter of Lord Scales
Vnto the Brother of your louing Bride;
Shee better would haue fitted me, or Clarence:
But in your Bride you burie Brotherhood.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Or else you would not haue bestow’d the Heire
Of the Lord Bonuill on your new Wiues Sonne,
And leaue your Brothers to goe ſpeede elsewhere.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Alas, poore Clarence: is it for a Wife
That thou art malecontent? I will prouide thee.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: In chusing for your ſelfe,
You ſhew’d your iudgement:
Which being ſhallow, you ſhall giue me leaue
To play the Broker in mine owne behalfe;
And to that end, I ſhortly minde to leaue you.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Leaue me, or tarry, Edward will be King,
And not be ty’d vnto his Brothers will.
Lady Grey.
My Lords, before it pleas’d his Maiestie
To rayse my State to Title of a Queene,
Doe me but right, and you must all confeſſe,
That I was not ignoble of Descent,
And meaner then my ſelfe haue had like fortune.
But as this Title honors me and mine,
So your dislikes, to whom I would be pleasing,
Doth cloud my ioyes with danger, and with ſorrow.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My Loue, forbeare to fawne vpon their frownes:
What danger, or what ſorrow can befall thee,
So long as Edward is thy constant friend,
And their true Soueraigne, whom they must obey?
Nay, whom they ſhall obey, and loue thee too,
Vnleſſe they ſeeke for hatred at my hands:
Which if they doe, yet will I keepe thee ſafe,
And they ſhall feele the vengeance of my wrath.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I heare, yet ſay not much, but thinke the more.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now Meſſenger, what Letters, or what Newes from France?

speech.speaker: Post.
speech.line: My Soueraigne Liege, no Letters, & few words,
But ſuch, as I (without your ſpeciall pardon)
Dare not relate.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Goe too, wee pardon thee:
Therefore, in briefe, tell me their words,
As neere as thou canst gueſſe them.
What anſwer makes King Lewis vnto our Letters?

speech.speaker: Post.
speech.line: At my depart, these were his very words:
Goe tell false Edward, the ſupposed King,
That Lewis of France is ſending ouer Maskers,
To reuell it with him, and his new Bride.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Is Lewis ſo braue? belike he thinkes me Henry.
But what ſaid Lady Bona to my Marriage?

speech.speaker: Post.
speech.line: These were her words, vtt'red with mild disdaine:
Tell him, in hope hee'le proue a Widower ſhortly,
Ile weare the Willow Garland for his ſake.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I blame not her; ſhe could ſay little leſſe:
She had the wrong. But what ſaid Henries Queene?
For I haue heard, that ſhe was there in place.

speech.speaker: Post.
speech.line: Tell him (quoth ſhe)
My mourning Weedes are done,
And I am readie to put Armour on.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Belike ſhe minds to play the Amazon.
But what ſaid Warwicke to these iniuries?

speech.speaker: Post.
speech.line: He, more incens’d against your Maiestie,
Then all the rest, discharg’d me with these words:
Tell him from me, that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore Ile vncrowne him, er't be long.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Ha? durst the Traytor breath out ſo prowd words?
Well, I will arme me, being thus fore-warn’d:
They ſhall haue Warres, and pay for their presumption.
But ſay, is Warwicke friends with Margaret?

speech.speaker: Post.
speech.line: I, gracious Soueraigne,
They are ſo link’d in friendship,
That yong Prince Edward marryes Warwicks Daughter.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: Belike, the elder;
Clarence will haue the younger.
Now Brother King farewell, and ſit you fast,
For I will hence to Warwickes other Daughter,
That though I want a Kingdome, yet in Marriage
I may not proue inferior to your ſelfe.
You that loue me, and Warwicke, follow me.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Not I:
My thoughts ayme at a further matter:
I ſtay not for the loue of Edward, but the Crowne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwicke?
Yet am I arm’d against the worst can happen:
And haste is needfull in this desp'rate case.
Pembrooke and Stafford, you in our behalfe
Goe leuie men, and make prepare for Warre;
They are alreadie, or quickly will be landed:
My ſelfe in person will ſtraight follow you.
But ere I goe, Hastings and Mountague
Resolue my doubt: you twaine, of all the rest,
Are neere to Warwicke, by bloud, and by allyance:
Tell me, if you loue Warwicke more then me;
If it be ſo, then both depart to him:
I rather wish you fœs, then hollow friends.
But if you minde to hold your true obedience,
Giue me aſſurance with ſome friendly Vow,
That I may neuer haue you in ſuspect.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: So God helpe Mountague, as hee proues true.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: And Hastings, as hee fauours Edwards cause.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now, Brother Richard, will you ſtand by vs?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, in despight of all that ſhall withstand you.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why ſo: then am I ſure of Victorie. Now therefore let vs hence, and lose no howre, Till wee meet Warwicke, with his forreine powre.

scene.stagedir: Enter Warwicke and Oxford in England, with French Souldiors

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Trust me, my Lord, all hitherto goes well,
The common people by numbers ſwarme to vs.
But ſee where Somerset and Clarence comes:
Speake ſuddenly, my Lords, are wee all friends?

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Feare not that, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Then gentle Clarence, welcome vnto Warwicke,
And welcome Somerset: I hold it cowardize,
To rest mistrustfull, where a Noble Heart
Hath pawn’d an open Hand, in ſigne of Loue;
Else might I thinke, that Clarence, Edwards Brother,
Were but a fained friend to our proceedings:
But welcome ſweet Clarence, my Daughter ſhall be thine.
And now, what rests? but in Nights Couerture,
Thy Brother being careleſſely encamp’d,
His Souldiors lurking in the Towne about,
And but attended by a ſimple Guard,
Wee may ſurprize and take him at our pleasure,
Our Scouts haue found the aduenture very easie:
That as Vlyſſes, and ſtout Diomede,
With ſleight and manhood ſtole to Rhesus Tents,
And brought from thence the Thracian fatall Steeds;
So wee, well couer’d with the Nights black Mantle,
At vnawares may beat downe Edwards Guard,
And ſeize himselfe: I ſay not, ſlaughter him,
For I intend but onely to ſurprize him.
You that will follow me to this attempt,
Applaud the Name of Henry, with your Leader.
Why then, let's on our way in ſilent ſort,
For Warwicke and his friends, God and Saint George.

scene.stagedir: Enter three Watchmen to guard the Kings Tent.

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: Come on my Masters, each man take his ſtand,
The King by this, is ſet him downe to ſleepe.

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: What, will he not to Bed?

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: Why, no: for he hath made a ſolemne Vow,
Neuer to lye and take his naturall Rest,
Till Warwicke, or himselfe, be quite ſupprest.

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: To morrow then belike ſhall be the day,
If Warwicke be ſo neere as men report.

speech.speaker: 3.Watch.
speech.line: But ſay, I pray, what Noble man is that,
That with the King here resteth in his Tent?

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: ‘Tis the Lord Hastings, the Kings chiefest friend.

speech.speaker: 3.Watch.
speech.line: O, is it ſo? but why commands the King,
That his chiefe followers lodge in Townes about him,
While he himselfe keepes in the cold field?

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: ‘Tis the more honour, because more dange-rous.

speech.speaker: 3.Watch.
speech.line: I, but giue me worship, and quietneſſe,
I like it better then a dangerous honor.
If Warwicke knew in what estate he ſtands,
‘Tis to be doubted if he would waken him.

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: Vnleſſe our Halberds did ſhut vp his pas-sage.

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: I: wherefore else guard we his Royall Tent, But to defend his Person from Night-fœs?

scene.stagedir: Enter Warwicke, Clarence, Oxford, Somerset, and French Souldiors, ſilent all

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: This is his Tent, and ſee where ſtand his Guard:
Courage my Masters: Honor now, or neuer:
But follow me, and Edward ſhall be ours.

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: Who goes there?

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: Stay, or thou dyest.

scene.stagedir: Warwicke and the rest cry all, Warwicke, Warwicke, and ſet vpon the Guard, who flye, crying, Arme, Arme, Warwicke and the rest following them
The Drumme playing, and Trumpet ſounding. Enter Warwicke, Somerset, and the rest, bringing the King out in his Gowne, ſitting in a Chaire: Richard and Hastings flyes ouer the Stage

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: What are they that flye there?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Richard and Hastings: let them goe, heere is the Duke.

speech.speaker: K.Edw.
speech.line: The Duke?
Why Warwicke, when wee parted,
Thou call’dst me King.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: I, but the case is alter’d.
When you disgrac’d me in my Embaſſade,
Then I degraded you from being King,
And come now to create you Duke of Yorke.
Alas, how ſhould you gouerne any Kingdome,
That know not how to vse Embaſſadors,
Nor how to be contented with one Wife,
Nor how to vse your Brothers Brotherly,
Nor how to ſtudie for the Peoples Welfare,
Nor how to ſhrowd your ſelfe from Enemies?

speech.speaker: K.Edw.
speech.line: Yea, Brother of Clarence,
Art thou here too?
Nay then I ſee, that Edward needs must downe.
Yet Warwicke, in despight of all mischance,
Of thee thy ſelfe, and all thy Complices,
Edward will alwayes beare himselfe as King:
Though Fortunes mallice ouerthrow my State,
My minde exceedes the compaſſe of her Wheele.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Then for his minde, be Edward Englands King,
But Henry now ſhall weare the English Crowne,
And be true King indeede: thou but the ſhadow.
My Lord of Somerset, at my request,
See that forthwith Duke Edward be conuey’d
Vnto my Brother Arch-Bishop of Yorke:
When I haue fought with Pembrooke, and his fellowes,
Ile follow you, and tell what anſwer
Lewis and the Lady Bona ſend to him.
Now for a-while farewell good Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: K.Ed.
speech.line: What Fates impose, that men must needs abide;
It boots not to resist both winde and tide.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: What now remaines my Lords for vs to do,
But march to London with our Soldiers?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I, that’s the first thing that we haue to do,
To free King Henry from imprisonment,
And ſee him ſeated in the Regall Throne.

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: Madam, what makes you in this ſodain change?

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: Why Brother Riuers, are you yet to learne
What late misfortune is befalne King Edward?

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: What loſſe of ſome pitcht battell
Against Warwicke?

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: No, but the loſſe of his owne Royall person.

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: Then is my Soueraigne ſlaine?

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: I almost ſlaine, for he is taken prisoner,
Either betrayd by falshood of his Guard,
Or by his Fœ ſurpriz’d at vnawares:
And as I further haue to vnderstand,
Is new committed to the Bishop of Yorke,
Fell Warwickes Brother, and by that our Fœ.

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: These Newes I must confeſſe are full of greefe,
Yet gracious Madam, beare it as you may,
Warwicke may loose, that now hath wonne the day.

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: Till then, faire hope must hinder liues decay:
And I the rather waine me from dispaire
For loue of Edwards Off-spring in my wombe:
This is it that makes me bridle paſſion,
And beare with Mildneſſe my misfortunes croſſe:
I, I, for this I draw in many a teare,
And ſtop the rising of blood-sucking ſighes,
Least with my ſighes or teares, I blast or drowne
King Edwards Fruite, true heyre to th’ English Crowne.

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: But Madam,
Where is Warwicke then become?

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: I am inform’d that he comes towards London,
To ſet the Crowne once more on Henries head,
Gueſſe thou the rest, King Edwards Friends must downe.
But to preuent the Tyrants violence,
(For trust not him that hath once broken Faith)
Ile hence forthwith vnto the Sanctuary,
To ſaue (at least) the heire of Edwards right:
There ſhall I rest ſecure from force and fraud:
Come therefore let vs flye, while we may flye,
If Warwicke take vs, we are ſure to dye.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard, Lord Hastings, and Sir William Stanley

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Now my Lord Hastings, and Sir William Stanley Leaue off to wonder why I drew you hither, Into this cheefest Thicket of the Parke. Thus ſtand the case: you know our King, my Brother, Is prisoner to the Bishop here, at whose hands He hath good vsage, and great liberty, And often but attended with weake guard, Come hunting this way to disport himselfe. I haue aduertis’d him by ſecret meanes, That if about this houre he make this way, Vnder the colour of his vsuall game, He ſhall heere finde his Friends with Horse and Men, To ſet him free from his Captiuitie.

scene.stagedir: Enter King Edward, and a Huntsman with him

speech.speaker: Huntsman.
speech.line: This way my Lord,
For this way lies the Game.
King Edw.
Nay this way man,
See where the Huntsmen ſtand.
Now Brother of Gloster, Lord Hastings, and the rest,
Stand you thus close to ſteale the Bishops Deere?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Brother, the time and case, requireth hast,
Your horse ſtands ready at the Parke-corner.
King Ed.
But whether ſhall we then?

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: To Lyn my Lord,
And ſhipt from thence to Flanders.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Wel guest beleeue me, for that was my meaning

speech.speaker: K.Ed.
speech.line: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardneſſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: But wherefore ſtay we? ‘tis no time to talke.

speech.speaker: K.Ed.
speech.line: Huntsman, what ſay'st thou?
Wilt thou go along?

speech.speaker: Hunts.
speech.line: Better do ſo, then tarry and be hang’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Come then away, lets ha no more adoo.

speech.speaker: K.Ed.
speech.line: Bishop farwell, Sheeld thee from Warwickes frowne, And pray that I may re-poſſeſſe the Crowne.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter King Henry the ſixt, Clarence, Warwicke, Somerset, young Henry, Oxford, Mountague, and Lieutenant

speech.speaker: K.Hen.
speech.line: M[aster]. Lieutenant, now that God and Friends
Haue ſhaken Edward from the Regall ſeate,
And turn’d my captiue ſtate to libertie,
My feare to hope, my ſorrowes vnto ioyes,
At our enlargement what are thy due Fees?

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Subiects may challenge nothing of their Sou'rains
But, if an humble prayer may preuaile,
I then craue pardon of your Maiestie.

speech.speaker: K.Hen.
speech.line: For what, Lieutenant? For well vsing me?
Nay, be thou ſure, Ile well requite thy kindneſſe.
For that it made my imprisonment, a pleasure:
I, ſuch a pleasure, as incaged Birds
Conceiue; when after many moody Thoughts,
At last, by Notes of Houshold harmonie,
They quite forget their loſſe of Libertie.
But Warwicke, after God, thou ſet'st me free,
And chiefely therefore, I thanke God, and thee,
He was the Author, thou the Instrument.
Therefore that I may conquer Fortunes ſpight,
By liuing low, where Fortune cannot hurt me,
And that the people of this bleſſed Land
May not be punisht with my thwarting ſtarres,
Warwicke, although my Head ſtill weare the Crowne,
I here resigne my Gouernment to thee,
For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Your Grace hath ſtill beene fam’d for vertuous,
And now may ſeeme as wise as vertuous,
By ſpying and auoiding Fortunes malice,
For few men rightly temper with the Starres:
Yet in this one thing let me blame your Grace,
For chusing me, when Clarence is in place.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: No Warwicke, thou art worthy of the ſway,
To whom the Heau'ns in thy Natiuitie,
Adiudg’d an Oliue Branch, and Lawrell Crowne,
As likely to be blest in Peace and Warre:
And therefore I yeeld thee my free consent.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And I chuse Clarence onely for Protector.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Warwick and Clarence, giue me both your Hands:
Now ioyne your Hands, & with your Hands your Hearts,
That no diſſention hinder Gouernment:
I make you both Protectors of this Land,
While I my ſelfe will lead a priuate Life,
And in deuotion ſpend my latter dayes,
To ſinnes rebuke, and my Creators prayse.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: What answeres Clarence to his Soueraignes will?

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: That he consents, if Warwicke yeeld consent,
For on thy fortune I repose my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Why then, though loth, yet must I be content:
Wee'le yoake together, like a double ſhadow
To Henries Body, and ſupply his place;
I meane, in bearing weight of Gouernment,
While he enioyes the Honor, and his ease.
And Clarence, now then it is more then needfull,
Forthwith that Edward be pronounc’d a Traytor,
And all his Lands and Goods confiscate.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: What else? and that Succeſſion be determined.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: I, therein Clarence ſhall not want his part.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But with the first, of all your chiefe affaires,
Let me entreat (for I command no more)
That Margaret your Queene, and my Sonne Edward,
Be ſent for, to returne from France with ſpeed:
For till I ſee them here, by doubtfull feare,
My ioy of libertie is halfe eclips’d.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: It ſhall bee done, my Soueraigne, with all ſpeede.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My Lord of Somerset, what Youth is that,
Of whom you ſeeme to haue ſo tender care?

speech.speaker: Somers.
speech.line: My Liege, it is young Henry, Earle of Rich-mond.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Come hither, Englands Hope:

line.stagedir: Layes his Hand on his Head.

speech.line: If ſecret Powers ſuggest but truth
To my diuining thoughts,
This prettie Lad will proue our Countries bliſſe.
His Lookes are full of peacefull Maiestie,
His Head by nature fram’d to weare a Crowne,
His Hand to wield a Scepter, and himselfe
Likely in time to bleſſe a Regall Throne:
Make much of him, my Lords; for this is hee
Must helpe you more, then you are hurt by mee.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: What newes, my friend?

speech.speaker: Poste.
speech.line: That Edward is escaped from your Brother,
And fled (as hee heares ſince) to Burgundie.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Vnsauorie newes: but how made he escape?

speech.speaker: Poste.
speech.line: He was conuey’d by Richard, Duke of Gloster,
And the Lord Hastings, who attended him
In ſecret ambush, on the Forrest ſide,
And from the Bishops Huntsmen rescu’d him:
For Hunting was his dayly Exercise.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: My Brother was too careleſſe of his charge.
But let vs hence, my Soueraigne, to prouide
A ſalue for any ſore, that may betide.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: My Lord, I like not of this flight of Edwards:
For doubtleſſe, Burgundie will yeeld him helpe,
And we ſhall haue more Warres befor't be long.
As Henries late presaging Prophecie
Did glad my heart, with hope of this young Richmond:
So doth my heart mis-giue me, in these Conflicts,
What may befall him, to his harme and ours.
Therefore, Lord Oxford, to preuent the worst,
Forthwith wee'le ſend him hence to Brittanie,
Till ſtormes be past of Ciuill Enmitie.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: I: for if Edward re-poſſeſſe the Crowne,
‘Tis like that Richmond, with the rest, ſhall downe.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: It ſhall be ſo: he ſhall to Brittanie. Come therefore, let's about it ſpeedily.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter Edward, Richard, Hastings, and Souldiers

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now Brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest,
Yet thus farre Fortune maketh vs amends,
And ſayes, that once more I ſhall enterchange
My wained ſtate, for Henries Regall Crowne.
Well haue we paſſ’d, and now re-paſſ’d the Seas,
And brought desired helpe from Burgundie.
What then remaines, we being thus arriu’d
From Rauenspurre Hauen, before the Gates of Yorke,
But that we enter, as into our Dukedome?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Gates made fast?
Brother, I like not this.
For many men that ſtumble at the Threshold,
Are well fore-told, that danger lurkes within.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Tuſh man, aboadments must not now affright vs:
By faire or foule meanes we must enter in,
For hither will our friends repaire to vs.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: My Liege, Ile knocke once more, to ſummon them.

scene.stagedir: Enter on the Walls, the Maior of Yorke, and his Brethren

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: My Lords,
We were fore-warned of your comming,
And ſhut the Gates, for ſafetie of our ſelues;
For now we owe allegeance vnto Henry.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: But, Master Maior, if Henry be your King,
Yet Edward, at the least, is Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: True, my good Lord, I know you for no leſſe.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Why, and I challenge nothing but my Dukedome,
As being well content with that alone.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: But when the Fox hath once got in his Nose,
Hee'le ſoone finde meanes to make the Body follow.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: Why, Master Maior, why ſtand you in a doubt?
Open the Gates, we are King Henries friends.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: I, ſay you ſo? the Gates ſhall then be opened.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: A wise ſtout Captaine, and ſoone perswaded.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: The good old man would faine that all were wel,
So 'twere not long of him: but being entred,
I doubt not I, but we ſhall ſoone perswade
Both him, and all his Brothers, vnto reason.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Maior, and two Aldermen.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: So, Master Maior: these Gates must not be ſhut, But in the Night, or in the time of Warre. What, feare not man, but yeeld me vp the Keyes, Takes his Keyes. For Edward will defend the Towne, and thee, And all those friends, that deine to follow mee.

scene.stagedir: March. Enter Mountgomerie, with Drumme and Souldiers

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Brother, this is Sir Iohn Mountgomerie,
Our trustie friend, vnleſſe I be deceiu’d.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Welcome Sir Iohn: but why come you in
Armes?

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: To helpe King Edward in his time of ſtorme,
As euery loyall Subiect ought to doe.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Thankes good Mountgomerie:
But we now forget our Title to the Crowne,
And onely clayme our Dukedome,
Till God please to ſend the rest.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Then fare you well, for I will hence againe,
I came to ſerue a King, and not a Duke:
Drummer ſtrike vp, and let vs march away.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Nay ſtay, Sir Iohn, a while, and wee'le debate
By what ſafe meanes the Crowne may be recouer’d.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: What talke you of debating? in few words,
If you'le not here proclaime your ſelfe our King,
Ile leaue you to your fortune, and be gone,
To keepe them back, that come to ſuccour you.
Why ſhall we fight, if you pretend no Title?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why Brother, wherefore ſtand you on nice points?

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: When wee grow ſtronger,
Then wee'le make our Clayme:
Till then, ‘tis wisdome to conceale our meaning.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: Away with ſcrupulous Wit, now Armes must rule.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And feareleſſe minds clyme ſoonest vnto Crowns.
Brother, we will proclaime you out of hand,
The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Then be it as you will: for ‘tis my right,
And Henry but vsurpes the Diademe.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: I, now my Soueraigne ſpeaketh like himselfe,
And now will I be Edwards Champion.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: Sound Trumpet, Edward ſhal be here proclaim’d:
Come, fellow Souldior, make thou proclamation.

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: Edward the Fourth, by the Grace of God, King of
England and France, and Lord of Ireland, &c.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: And whosœ're gainsayes King Edwards right,
By this I challenge him to ſingle fight.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Long liue Edward the Fourth.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Thankes braue Mountgomery,
And thankes vnto you all:
If fortune ſerue me, Ile requite this kindneſſe.
Now for this Night, let's harbor here in Yorke:
And when the Morning Sunne ſhall rayse his Carre
Aboue the Border of this Horizon,
Wee'le forward towards Warwicke, and his Mates;
For well I wot, that Henry is no Souldier.
Ah froward Clarence, how euill it beseemes thee,
To flatter Henry, and forsake thy Brother?
Yet as wee may, wee'le meet both thee and Warwicke.
Come on braue Souldiors: doubt not of the Day,
And that once gotten, doubt not of large Pay.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the King, Warwicke, Mountague, Clarence, Oxford, and Somerset

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: What counsaile, Lords? Edward from Belgia,
With hastie Germanes, and blunt Hollanders,
Hath paſſ’d in ſafetie through the Narrow Seas,
And with his troupes doth march amaine to London,
And many giddie people flock to him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Let's leuie men, and beat him backe againe.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: A little fire is quickly trodden out,
Which being ſuffer’d, Riuers cannot quench.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: In Warwickshire I haue true-hearted friends,
Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in Warre,
Those will I muster vp: and thou Sonne Clarence
Shalt ſtirre vp in Suffolke, Norfolke, and in Kent,
The Knights and Gentlemen, to come with thee.
Thou Brother Mountague, in Buckingham,
Northampton, and in Leicestershire, ſhalt find
Men well enclin’d to heare what thou command'st.
And thou, braue Oxford, wondrous well belou’d,
In Oxfordshire ſhalt muster vp thy friends.
My Soueraigne, with the louing Citizens,
Like to his Iland, gyrt in with the Ocean,
Or modest Dyan, circled with her Nymphs,
Shall rest in London, till we come to him:
Faire Lords take leaue, and ſtand not to reply.
Farewell my Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Farewell my Hector, and my Troyes true hope.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: In ſigne of truth, I kiſſe your Highneſſe Hand.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Comfort, my Lord, and ſo I take my leaue.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: And thus I ſeale my truth, and bid adieu.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Sweet Oxford, and my louing Mountague,
And all at once, once more a happy farewell.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Farewell, ſweet Lords, let's meet at Couentry.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Here at the Pallace will I rest a while.
Cousin of Exeter, what thinkes your Lordship?
Me thinkes, the Power that Edward hath in field,
Should not be able to encounter mine.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: The doubt is, that he will ſeduce the rest.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: That's not my feare, my meed hath got me fame:
I haue not ſtopt mine eares to their demands,
Nor posted off their ſuites with ſlow delayes,
My pittie hath beene balme to heale their wounds,
My mildneſſe hath allay’d their ſwelling griefes,
My mercie dry’d their water-flowing teares.
I haue not been desirous of their wealth,
Nor much opprest them with great Subsidies,
Nor forward of reuenge, though they much err’d.
Then why ſhould they loue Edward more then me?
No Exeter, these Graces challenge Grace:
And when the Lyon fawnes vpon the Lambe,
The Lambe will neuer cease to follow him.

scene.stagedir: Shout within, A Lancaster, A Lancaster.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: Hearke, hearke, my Lord, what Shouts are these?

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Seize on the ſhamefac’d Henry, beare him hence,
And once againe proclaime vs King of England.
You are the Fount, that makes ſmall Brookes to flow,
Now ſtops thy Spring, my Sea ſhall ſuck them dry,
And ſwell ſo much the higher, by their ebbe.
Hence with him to the Tower, let him not ſpeake.
And Lords, towards Couentry bend we our course,
Where peremptorie Warwicke now remaines:
The Sunne ſhines hot, and if we vse delay,
Cold biting Winter marres our hop’d-for Hay.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Away betimes, before his forces ioyne,
And take the great-growne Traytor vnawares:
Braue Warriors, march amaine towards Couentry.

scene.stagedir: Enter Warwicke, the Maior of Couentry, two Meſſengers, and others vpon the Walls

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Where is the Post that came from valiant Oxford?
How farre hence is thy Lord, mine honeſt fellow?

speech.speaker: Meſſ. 1.
speech.line: By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: How farre off is our Brother Mountague?
Where is the Post that came from Mountague?

speech.speaker: Meſſ. 2.
speech.line: By this at Daintry, with a puiſſant troope.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Say Someruile, what ſayes my louing Sonne?
And by thy gueſſe, how nigh is Clarence now?

speech.speaker: Someru.
speech.line: At Southam I did leaue him with his forces,
And doe expect him here ſome two howres hence.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Then Clarence is at hand, I heare his Drumme.

speech.speaker: Someru.
speech.line: It is not his, my Lord, here Southam lyes:
The Drum your Honor heares, marcheth from Warwicke.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Who ſhould that be? belike vnlook’d for friends.

speech.speaker: Someru.
speech.line: They are at hand, and you ſhall quickly know.

scene.stagedir: March. Flourish. Enter Edward, Richard, and Souldiers

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Goe, Trumpet, to the Walls, and ſound a Parle.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: See how the ſurly Warwicke mans the Wall.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Oh vnbid ſpight, is ſportfull Edward come?
Where ſlept our Scouts, or how are they ſeduc’d,
That we could heare no newes of his repayre.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now Warwicke, wilt thou ope the Citie Gates,
Speake gentle words, and humbly bend thy Knee,
Call Edward King, and at his hands begge Mercy,
And he ſhall pardon thee these Outrages?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Nay rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence,
Confeſſe who ſet thee vp, and pluckt thee downe,
Call Warwicke Patron, and be penitent,
And thou ſhalt ſtill remaine the Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I thought at least he would haue ſaid the King,
Or did he make the Ieast against his will?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Is not a Dukedome, Sir, a goodly gift?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, by my faith, for a poore Earle to giue,
Ile doe thee ſeruice for ſo good a gift.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: 'Twas I that gaue the Kingdome to thy Bro-ther.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Why then ‘tis mine, if but by Warwickes gift.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Thou art no Atlas for ſo great a weight:
And Weakeling, Warwicke takes his gift againe,
And Henry is my King, Warwicke his Subiect.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: But Warwickes King is Edwards Prisoner:
And gallant Warwicke, doe but anſwer this,
What is the Body, when the Head is off?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Alas, that Warwicke had no more fore-cast,
But whiles he thought to ſteale the ſingle Ten,
The King was ſlyly finger’d from the Deck:
You left poore Henry at the Bishops Pallace,
And tenne to one you'le meet him in the Tower.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: ‘Tis euen ſo, yet you are Warwicke ſtill.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Come Warwicke,
Take the time, kneele downe, kneele downe:
Nay when? ſtrike now, or else the Iron cooles.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I had rather chop this Hand off at a blow,
And with the other, fling it at thy face,
Then beare ſo low a ſayle, to ſtrike to thee.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Sayle how thou canst,
Haue Winde and Tyde thy friend,
This Hand, fast wound about thy coale-black hayre,
Shall, whiles thy Head is warme, and new cut off,
Write in the dust this Sentence with thy blood,
Wind-changing Warwicke now can change no more.

scene.stagedir: Enter Oxford, with Drumme and Colours.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Oh chearefull Colours, ſee where Oxford comes.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Gates are open, let vs enter too.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: So other fœs may ſet vpon our backs.
Stand we in good array: for they no doubt
Will iſſue out againe, and bid vs battaile;
If not, the Citie being but of ſmall defence,
Wee'le quickly rowze the Traitors in the ſame.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Oh welcome Oxford, for we want thy helpe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Mountague, with Drumme and Colours.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Mountague, Mountague, for Lancaster.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thou and thy Brother both ſhall buy this Treason
Euen with the dearest blood your bodies beare.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: The harder matcht, the greater Victorie,
My minde presageth happy gaine, and Conquest.

scene.stagedir: Enter Somerset, with Drumme and Colours.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Two of thy Name, both Dukes of Somerset,
Haue ſold their Liues vnto the House of Yorke,
And thou ſhalt be the third, if this Sword hold.

scene.stagedir: Enter Clarence, with Drumme and Colours.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: And lœ, where George of Clarence ſweepes along,
Of force enough to bid his Brother Battaile:
With whom, in vpright zeale to right, preuailes
More then the nature of a Brothers Loue.
Come Clarence, come: thou wilt, if Warwicke call.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Father of Warwicke, know you what this meanes?
Looke here, I throw my infamie at thee:
I will not ruinate my Fathers House,
Who gaue his blood to lyme the ſtones together,
And ſet vp Lancaster. Why, trowest thou, Warwicke,
That Clarence is ſo harsh, ſo blunt, vnnaturall,
To bend the fatall Instruments of Warre
Against his Brother, and his lawfull King.
Perhaps thou wilt obiect my holy Oath:
To keepe that Oath, were more impietie,
Then Iephah, when he ſacrific’d his Daughter.
I am ſo ſorry for my Trespas made,
That to deserue well at my Brothers hands,
I here proclayme my ſelfe thy mortall fœ:
With resolution, wheresœ're I meet thee,
(As I will meet thee, if thou ſtirre abroad)
To plague thee, for thy foule mis-leading me.
And ſo, prowd-hearted Warwicke, I defie thee,
And to my Brother turne my blushing Cheekes.
Pardon me Edward, I will make amends:
And Richard, doe not frowne vpon my faults,
For I will henceforth be no more vnconstant.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now welcome more, and ten times more belou’d,
Then if thou neuer hadst deseru’d our hate.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Welcome good Clarence, this is Brother-like.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Oh paſſing Traytor, periur’d and vniust.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: What Warwicke,
Wilt thou leaue the Towne, and fight?
Or ſhall we beat the Stones about thine Eares?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Alas, I am not coop’d here for defence:
I will away towards Barnet presently,
And bid thee Battaile, Edward, if thou dar'st.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Yes Warwicke, Edward dares, and leads the way: Lords to the field: Saint George, and Victorie.

scene.stagedir: March. Warwicke and his companie followes.
Alarum, and Excursions. Enter Edward bringing forth Warwicke wounded

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: So, lye thou there: dye thou, and dye our feare,
For Warwicke was a Bugge that fear’d vs all.
Now Mountague ſit fast, I ſeeke for thee,
That Warwickes Bones may keepe thine companie.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Ah, who is nigh? come to me, friend, or fœ,
And tell me who is Victor, Yorke, or Warwicke?
Why aske I that? my mangled body ſhewes,
My blood, my want of ſtrength, my ſicke heart ſhewes,
That I must yeeld my body to the Earth,
And by my fall, the conquest to my fœ.
Thus yeelds the Cedar to the Axes edge,
Whose Armes gaue ſhelter to the Princely Eagle,
Vnder whose ſhade the ramping Lyon ſlept,
Whose top-branch ouer-peer’d Ioues ſpreading Tree,
And kept low Shrubs from Winters pow'rfull Winde.
These Eyes, that now are dim’d with Deaths black Veyle,
Haue beene as piercing as the Mid-day Sunne,
To ſearch the ſecret Treasons of the World:
The Wrinckles in my Browes, now fill’d with blood,
Were lik'ned oft to Kingly Sepulchers:
For who liu’d King, but I could digge his Graue?
And who durst ſmile, when Warwicke bent his Brow?
Lœ, now my Glory ſmear’d in dust and blood.
My Parkes, my Walkes, my Mannors that I had,
Euen now forsake me; and of all my Lands,
Is nothing left me, but my bodies length.
Why, what is Pompe, Rule, Reigne, but Earth and Dust?
And liue we how we can, yet dye we must.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Ah Warwicke, Warwicke, wert thou as we are,
We might recouer all our Loſſe againe:
The Queene from France hath brought a puiſſant power.
Euen now we heard the newes: ah, could'st thou flye.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Why then I would not flye. Ah Mountague,
If thou be there, ſweet Brother, take my Hand,
And with thy Lippes keepe in my Soule a while.
Thou lou'st me not: for, Brother, if thou did'st,
Thy teares would wash this cold congealed blood,
That glewes my Lippes, and will not let me ſpeake.
Come quickly Mountague, or I am dead.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Ah Warwicke, Mountague hath breath’d his last,
And to the latest gaspe, cry’d out for Warwicke:
And ſaid, Commend me to my valiant Brother.
And more he would haue ſaid, and more he ſpoke,
Which ſounded like a Cannon in a Vault,
That mought not be distinguisht: but at last,
I well might heare, deliuered with a groane,
Oh farewell Warwicke.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Sweet rest his Soule:
Flye Lords, and ſaue your ſelues,
For Warwicke bids you all farewell, to meet in Heauen.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Away, away, to meet the Queenes great power.

scene.stagedir: Here they beare away his Body. Exeunt.
Flourish. Enter King Edward in triumph, with Richard, Clarence, and the rest

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thus farre our fortune keepes an vpward course,
And we are grac’d with wreaths of Victorie:
But in the midst of this bright-shining Day,
I ſpy a black ſuspicious threatning Cloud,
That will encounter with our glorious Sunne,
Ere he attaine his easefull Westerne Bed:
I meane, my Lords, those powers that the Queene
Hath rays’d in Gallia, haue arriued our Coast,
And, as we heare, march on to fight with vs.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: A little gale will ſoone disperse that Cloud,
And blow it to the Source from whence it came,
Thy very Beames will dry those Vapours vp,
For euery Cloud engenders not a Storme.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Queene is valued thirtie thousand ſtrong,
And Somerset, with Oxford, fled to her:
If ſhe haue time to breathe, be well aſſur’d
Her faction will be full as ſtrong as ours.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We are aduertis’d by our louing friends,
That they doe hold their course toward Tewksbury.
We hauing now the best at Barnet field,
Will thither ſtraight, for willingneſſe rids way,
And as we march, our ſtrength will be augmented:
In euery Countie as we goe along,
Strike vp the Drumme, cry courage, and away.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. March. Enter the Queene, young Edward, Somerset, Oxford, and Souldiers

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Great Lords, wise men ne'r ſit and waile their loſſe,
But chearely ſeeke how to redreſſe their harmes.
What though the Mast be now blowne ouer-boord,
The Cable broke, the holding-Anchor lost,
And halfe our Saylors ſwallow’d in the flood?
Yet liues our Pilot ſtill. Is't meet, that hee
Should leaue the Helme, and like a fearefull Lad,
With tearefull Eyes adde Water to the Sea,
And giue more ſtrength to that which hath too much,
Whiles in his moane, the Ship ſplits on the Rock,
Which Industrie and Courage might haue ſau’d?
Ah what a ſhame, ah what a fault were this.
Say Warwicke was our Anchor: what of that?
And Mountague our Top-Mast: what of him?
Our ſlaught'red friends, the Tackles: what of these?
Why is not Oxford here, another Anchor?
And Somerset, another goodly Mast?
The friends of France our Shrowds and Tacklings?
And though vnskilfull, why not Ned and I,
For once allow’d the ſkilfull Pilots Charge?
We will not from the Helme, to ſit and weepe,
But keepe our Course (though the rough Winde ſay no)
From Shelues and Rocks, that threaten vs with Wrack.
As good to chide the Waues, as ſpeake them faire.
And what is Edward, but a ruthleſſe Sea?
What Clarence, but a Quick-sand of Deceit?
And Richard, but a raged fatall Rocke?
All these, the Enemies to our poore Barke.
Say you can ſwim, alas ‘tis but a while:
Tread on the Sand, why there you quickly ſinke,
Bestride the Rock, the Tyde will wash you off,
Or else you famish, that’s a three-fold Death.
This ſpeake I (Lords) to let you vnderstand,
If case ſome one of you would flye from vs,
That there's no hop’d-for Mercy with the Brothers,
More then with ruthleſſe Waues, with Sands and Rocks.
Why courage then, what cannot be auoided,
'Twere childish weakeneſſe to lament, or feare.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Me thinkes a Woman of this valiant Spirit,
Should, if a Coward heard her ſpeake these words,
Infuse his Breast with Magnanimitie,
And make him, naked, foyle a man at Armes.
I ſpeake not this, as doubting any here:
For did I but ſuspect a fearefull man,
He ſhould haue leaue to goe away betimes,
Least in our need he might infect another,
And make him of like ſpirit to himselfe.
If any ſuch be here, as God forbid,
Let him depart, before we neede his helpe.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Women and Children of ſo high a courage,
And Warriors faint, why 'twere perpetuall ſhame.
Oh braue young Prince: thy famous Grandfather
Doth liue againe in thee; long may'st thou liue,
To beare his Image, and renew his Glories.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: And he that will not fight for ſuch a hope,
Goe home to Bed, and like the Owle by day,
If he arise, be mock’d and wondred at.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Thankes gentle Somerset, ſweet Oxford thankes.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: And take his thankes, that yet hath nothing else.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Prepare you Lords, for Edward is at hand,
Readie to fight: therefore be resolute.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: I thought no leſſe: it is his Policie,
To haste thus fast, to finde vs vnprouided.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: But hee's deceiu’d, we are in readineſſe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: This cheares my heart, to ſee your forwardneſſe.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Here pitch our Battaile, hence we will not budge.

scene.stagedir: Flourish, and march. Enter Edward, Richard, Clarence, and Souldiers

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Braue followers, yonder ſtands the thornie Wood,
Which by the Heauens aſſistance, and your ſtrength,
Must by the Roots be hew'ne vp yet ere Night.
I need not adde more fuell to your fire,
For well I wot, ye blaze, to burne them out:
Giue ſignall to the fight, and to it Lords.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Lords, Knights, and Gentlemen, what I ſhould ſay,
My teares gaine-say: for euery word I ſpeake,
Ye ſee I drinke the water of my eye.
Therefore no more but this: Henry your Soueraigne
Is Prisoner to the Fœ, his State vsurp’d,
His Realme a ſlaughter-house, his Subiects ſlaine,
His Statutes cancell’d, and his Treasure ſpent:
And yonder is the Wolfe, that makes this ſpoyle.
You fight in Iustice: then in Gods Name, Lords,
Be valiant, and giue ſignall to the fight.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter Edward, Richard, Queene, Clarence, Oxford, Somerset

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now here a period of tumultuous Broyles.
Away with Oxford, to Hames Castle ſtraight:
For Somerset, off with his guiltie Head.
Goe beare them hence, I will not heare them ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: For my part, Ile not trouble thee with words.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Nor I, but ſtoupe with patience to my fortune.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: So part we ſadly in this troublous World,
To meet with Ioy in ſweet Ierusalem.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Is Proclamation made, That who finds Edward,
Shall haue a high Reward, and he his Life?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: It is, and lœ where youthfull Edward comes.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Bring forth the Gallant, let vs heare him ſpeake.
What? can ſo young a Thorne begin to prick?
Edward, what ſatisfaction canst thou make,
For bearing Armes, for ſtirring vp my Subiects,
And all the trouble thou hast turn’d me to?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Speake like a Subiect, prowd ambitious Yorke.
Suppose that I am now my Fathers Mouth,
Resigne thy Chayre, and where I ſtand, kneele thou,
Whil'st I propose the ſelfe-ſame words to thee,
Which (Traytor) thou would'st haue me anſwer to.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Ah, that thy Father had beene ſo resolu’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: That you might ſtill haue worne the Petticoat,
And ne're haue ſtolne the Breech from Lancaster.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Let Aesop fable in a Winters Night,
His Currish Riddles ſorts not with this place.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: By Heauen, Brat, Ile plague ye for that word.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: I, thou wast borne to be a plague to men.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: For Gods ſake, take away this Captiue Scold.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Nay, take away this ſcolding Crooke-backe, rather.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Peace wilfull Boy, or I will charme your tongue.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Vntutor’d Lad, thou art too malapert.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: I know my dutie, you are all vndutifull:
Lasciuious Edward, and thou periur’d George,
And thou mis-shapen Dicke, I tell ye all,
I am your better, Traytors as ye are,
And thou vsurp'st my Fathers right and mine.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Take that, the likeneſſe of this Rayler here.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Sprawl'st thou? take that, to end thy agonie.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: And ther's for twitting me with periurie.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Oh, kill me too.

speech.speaker: Rich
speech.line: Marry, and ſhall.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Hold, Richard, hold, for we haue done too much.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why ſhould ſhee liue, to fill the World with words.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: What? doth ſhee ſwowne? vse meanes for her recouerie.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Clarence excuse me to the King my Brother:
Ile hence to London on a ſerious matter,
Ere ye come there, be ſure to heare ſome newes.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: What? what?

speech.speaker: Rich
speech.line: Tower, the Tower.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Oh Ned, ſweet Ned, ſpeake to thy Mother Boy.
Can'st thou not ſpeake? O Traitors, Murtherers!
They that ſtabb’d Caesar, ſhed no blood at all:
Did not offend, nor were not worthy Blame,
If this foule deed were by, to equall it.
He was a Man; this (in respect) a Childe,
And Men, ne're ſpend their fury on a Childe.
What's worse then Murtherer, that I may name it?
No, no, my heart will burst, and if I ſpeake,
And I will ſpeake, that ſo my heart may burst.
Butchers and Villaines, bloudy Caniballes,
How ſweet a Plant haue you vntimely cropt:
You haue no children (Butchers) if you had,
The thought of them would haue ſtirr’d vp remorse,
But if you euer chance to haue a Childe,
Looke in his youth to haue him ſo cut off.
As deathsmen you haue rid this ſweet yong Prince.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Away with her, go beare her hence perforce.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Nay, neuer beare me hence, dispatch me heere:
Here ſheath thy Sword, Ile pardon thee my death:
What? wilt thou not? Then Clarence do it thou.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: By heauen, I will not do thee ſo much ease.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Good Clarence do: ſweet Clarence do thou do it.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Did'st thou not heare me ſweare I would not do it?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: I, but thou vsest to forsweare thy ſelfe.
'Twas Sin before, but now ‘tis Charity
What wilt y not? Where is that diuels butcher Richard?
Hard fauor’d Richard? Richard, where art thou?
Thou art not heere; Murther is thy Almes-deed:
Petitioners for Blood, thou ne're put'st backe.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Away I ſay, I charge ye beare her hence,

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: So come to you, and yours, as to this Prince.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Where's Richard gone.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: To London all in post, and as I gueſſe,
To make a bloody Supper in the Tower.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: He's ſodaine if a thing comes in his head. Now march we hence, discharge the common ſort With Pay and Thankes, and let's away to London, And ſee our gentle Queene how well ſhe fares, By this (I hope) ſhe hath a Sonne for me.

scene.stagedir: Enter Henry the ſixt, and Richard, with the Lieutenant on the Walles

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Good day, my Lord, what at your Booke ſo hard?

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: I my good Lord: my Lord I ſhould ſay rather,
Tis ſinne to flatter, Good was little better:
'Good Gloster, and good Deuill, were alike,
And both preposterous: therefore, not Good Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Sirra, leaue vs to our ſelues, we must conferre.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: So flies the wreakleſſe ſhepherd from y Wolfe:
So first the harmleſſe Sheepe doth yeeld his Fleece,
And next his Throate, vnto the Butchers Knife.
What Scene of death hath Roſſius now to Acte?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Suspition alwayes haunts the guilty minde,
The Theefe doth feare each bush an Officer,

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: The Bird that hath bin limed in a bush,
With trembling wings misdoubteth euery bush;
And I the hapleſſe Male to one ſweet Bird,
Haue now the fatall Obiect in my eye,
Where my poore yong was lim’d, was caught, and kill’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why what a peeuish Foole was that of Creet,
That taught his Sonne the office of a Fowle,
And yet for all his wings, the Foole was drown’d.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: I Dedalus, my poore Boy Icarus,
Thy Father Minos, that deni’de our course,
The Sunne that ſear’d the wings of my ſweet Boy.
Thy Brother Edward, and thy Selfe, the Sea
Whose enuious Gulfe did ſwallow vp his life:
Ah, kill me with thy Weapon, not with words,
My brest can better brooke thy Daggers point,
Then can my eares that Tragicke History.
But wherefore dost thou come? Is't for my Life?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Think'st thou I am an Executioner?

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: A Persecutor I am ſure thou art,
If murthering Innocents be Executing,
Why then thou art an Executioner.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thy Son I kill’d for his presumption.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Hadst thou bin kill’d, when first y didst presume,
Thou had'st not liu’d to kill a Sonne of mine:
And thus I prophesie, that many a thousand,
Which now mistrust no parcell of my feare,
And many an old mans ſighe, and many a Widdowes,
And many an Orphans water-standing-eye,
Men for their Sonnes, Wiues for their Husbands,
Orphans, for their Parents timeles death,
Shall rue the houre that euer thou was't borne.
The Owle ſhriek’d at thy birth, an euill ſigne,
The Night-Crow cry’de, aboding luckleſſe time,
Dogs howl’d, and hiddeous Tempest ſhook down Trees:
The Rauen rook’d her on the Chimnies top,
And chatt'ring Pies in dismall Discords ſung:
Thy Mother felt more then a Mothers paine,
And yet brought forth leſſe then a Mothers hope,
To wit, an indigested and deformed lumpe,
Not like the fruit of ſuch a goodly Tree.
Teeth had'st thou in thy head, when thou was't borne,
To ſignifie, thou cam'st to bite the world:
And if the rest be true, which I haue heard,
Thou cam'st—

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ile heare no more:
Dye Prophet in thy ſpeech,
For this (among'st the rest) was I ordain’d.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: I, and for much more ſlaughter after this,
O God forgiue my ſinnes, and pardon thee.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: What? will the aspiring blood of Lancaster
Sinke in the ground? I thought it would haue mounted.
See how my ſword weepes for the poore Kings death.
O may ſuch purple teares be alway ſhed
From those that wish the downfall of our house.
If any ſparke of Life be yet remaining,
Downe, downe to hell, and ſay I ſent thee thither.
I that haue neyther pitty, loue, nor feare,
Indeed ‘tis true that Henrie told me of:
For I haue often heard my Mother ſay,
I came into the world with my Legges forward.
Had I not reason (thinke ye) to make hast,
And ſeeke their Ruine, that vsurp’d our Right?
The Midwife wonder’d, and the Women cri’de
O Iesus bleſſe vs, he is borne with teeth,
And ſo I was, which plainly ſignified,
That I ſhould ſnarle, and bite, and play the dogge:
Then ſince the Heauens haue ſhap’d my Body ſo,
Let Hell make crook’d my Minde to anſwer it.
I haue no Brother, I am like no Brother:
And this word (Loue) which Gray-beards call Diuine,
Be resident in men like one another,
And not in me: I am my ſelfe alone.
Clarence beware, thou keept'st me from the Light,
But I will ſort a pitchy day for thee:
For I will buzze abroad ſuch Prophesies,
That Edward ſhall be fearefull of his life,
And then to purge his feare, Ile be thy death.
King Henry, and the Prince his Son are gone,
Clarence thy turne is next, and then the rest,
Counting my ſelfe but bad, till I be best.
Ile throw thy body in another roome,
And Triumph Henry, in thy day of Doome.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter King, Queene, Clarence, Richard, Hastings, Nurse, and Attendants

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Once more we ſit in Englands Royall Throne,
Re-purchac’d with the Blood of Enemies:
What valiant Fœ-men, like to Autumnes Corne,
Haue we mow’d downe in tops of all their pride?
Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold Renowne,
For hardy and vndoubted Champions:
Two Cliffords, as the Father and the Sonne,
And two Northumberlands: two brauer men,
Ne're ſpurr’d their Coursers at the Trumpets ſound.
With them, the two braue Beares, Warwick & Montague,
That in their Chaines fetter’d the Kingly Lyon,
And made the Forrest tremble when they roar’d.
Thus haue we ſwept Suspition from our Seate,
And made our Footstoole of Security.
Come hither Beſſe, and let me kiſſe my Boy:
Yong Ned, for thee, thine Vnckles, and my ſelfe,
Haue in our Armors watcht the Winters night,
Went all afoote in Summers ſcalding heate,
That thou might'st repoſſeſſe the Crowne in peace,
And of our Labours thou ſhalt reape the gaine.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ile blast his Haruest, if your head were laid,
For yet I am not look’d on in the world.
This ſhoulder was ordain’d ſo thicke, to heaue,
And heaue it ſhall ſome waight, or breake my backe,
Worke thou the way, and that ſhalt execute.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Clarence and Gloster, loue my louely Queene,
And kis your Princely Nephew Brothers both.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: The duty that I owe vnto your Maiesty,
I Seale vpon the lips of this ſweet Babe.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Thanke Noble Clarence, worthy brother thanks.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And that I loue the tree fro[m] whence y ſprang'st:
Witneſſe the louing kiſſe I giue the Fruite,
To ſay the truth, ſo Iudas kist his master,
And cried all haile, when as he meant all harme.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now am I ſeated as my ſoule delights,
Hauing my Countries peace, and Brothers loues.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: What will your Grace haue done with Margaret,
Reynard her Father, to the King of France
Hath pawn’d the Sicils and Ierusalem,
And hither haue they ſent it for her ransome.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Away with her, and waft her hence to France:
And now what rests, but that we ſpend the time
With ſtately Triumphes, mirthfull Comicke ſhewes,
Such as befits the pleasure of the Court.
Sound Drums and Trumpets, farwell ſowre annoy,
For heere I hope begins our lasting ioy.
